content:
r 25, 2015
												I have to admit that I avoided Dark Souls for an unhealthy amount of time. Rarely playing games above the normal difficulty, the appeal of it being a really hard and unforgiving game wasn't the most compelling. I'm glad I changed my mind though, because I may have had missed out on a game I now consider one of the best of the decade.The gameplay is fun and engaging. The art, hauntingly beautiful and original. The soundtrack, breathtaking. But what really makes Dark Souls a masterpiece, by perfectly uniting all its elements, is the world of Lordran. Its cohesive design made me question every videogame world I'd experienced up to that point. From the wastes below the very backbone of the land up to the very top of the tallest tower of the tallest castle, the world's vertical and intrinsic design never fails to maintain its authenticity and unimpaired flow. After transversing the map not too many times, I could - and still can, months after actively playing the game - definitely draw a convincing transcription of it, with all its shortcuts and intersections. In a journey through Lordram, rarely does it feel like an area is forgettable or unused.Dark Souls has no narrative. There are no quests, maps, or journals. What it has is the world of Lordran. The story is presented to the player through unusual elements. Item descriptions. NPCs - that have their own agenda. And most importantly, through the other main elements of the game: music, visuals, gameplay. You are never given a codex or anything like what most RPGs have. You have to pay attention and intentionally pursue the story elements to make any sense out of it. Or you can ignore that and go slay a wide array of creatures and superbly designed bosses - it's just as fun. As is taking part in the clever and unique co-op and PvP elements. To top it all off, the atmosphere through most of the game is unmatched. But that comes as no surprise after praising the world and its cohesiveness for so long.A must-play if I've ever seen one, Dark Souls is as a fresh experience as it is a throwback to a kind of fun recent videogames seemed to have forgotten.

number of helpful: 494 of 672 people (74%) found this review helpful12 people found this review funny
content:
3, 2014
												Dark Souls: Prepare To Dye Edition is the latest installment in a series of family games by critically acclaimed developer From Software. In it, you take on the role of a young Italian painter by the name of Adriano Abato, on his quest to restore color to the world and solve the mystery of why it was lost to begin with. Adriano is joined by his talking pet dog, Francesco, who brings some much needed levity to their journey with his many hilarious puns. Francesco has more to offer than just his sense of humor, however, and his tail doubles as a magical paintbrush to help Adriano return color to the world.Gameplay (8/10)The goal of the game is to obtain colors and then use them to return color to a monochrome world with your paintbrush. The more of the world that is restored this way, the closer to solving the mystery Adriano gets. While it is not necessary to repaint 100% of the world, there is a special secret in store for players with the patience and dedication to do so.The gameplay is split into four phases. In the first phase, Adriano and Francesco must travel to an area that has lost its colors. It's up to the player to decide where to go first, but some locations have a higher difficulty level than others. Decide for yourself what you feel capable of, but try to challenge your creative spirit!In the second phase, Adriano must find the Three Prime Colors of the area in question and convince them to aid him in restoring color to their surroundings. The three different Colors are Yellow, Blue and Red. Yellows will usually aid Adriano willingly because of their desire to return color to the sun, but in some cases Adriano will have to solve a riddle or prove himself first. Blues can be troublesome, particularly if Adriano hasn't restored a lot of churches yet. In most cases they will give Adriano a puzzle to solve, the difficulty of which depends on how much of the world's color has already been restored. The most troublesome Color by far is Red. The Reds will often say mean-spirited things to poor Adriano and try to ruin his paintings. They can be difficult to deal with, but with a bit of cunning and a hysterical joke from Francesco, Adriano will eventually be able to prevail.In the third phase, Adriano has to apply these colors to the canvas that is the monochrome world. Here, accuracy, speed and the number of colors collected is important. If Adriano gets careless he might not be able to properly restore color to the world, and if he is too slow the Colors might get impatient and escape again.The fourth phase is only unlocked after Adriano has restored a sufficient amount of the world's color. I won't spoil the details of this phase, but it's quite intense!There is also a competitive multiplayer mode for up to four players where you compete to color a monochrome landscape as fast and as accurately as possible. There are some connectivity issues on the PC version, but with a bit of patience it shouldn't be hard to gather players for some creative painting fun.I give this game an 8/10 for the gameplay, which is both fun and addictive. The competitive multiplayer mode is particularly riveting, and many an evening was swallowed up in endless sessions of painting masterpieces with my fellow art enthusiasts from all over the world.Story (7/10)Prepare to Dye does not have a very complex storyline, but it doesn't need one, either. It's a family game for casual painting fun, and the plot reflects this. It's simple enough that a child can grasp it, but even adults will appreciate the tale of Adriano in the monochrome world. The twist at the end will also likely surprise most players, even if there are some clues to this twist scattered throughout the game. This is only obvious in retrospect, however.I give the story a 7/10, because while the story is not particularly advanced it does get the job done. It suits the game, and does not get too ambitious or take itself too seriously. It's a story anyone can jump into and enjoy.Characters (6/10)The primary characters are Adriano and Francesco. Adriano is a cheerful young artist with a knack for making those around him smile. His optimistic and carefree nature allowed him to avoid the influence of the monochrome world, and he now wants to restore color to the rest of the world. Francesco, his talking dog, is similar to his owner in many ways, but has a knack for clever wordplay that sometimes goes over Adriano's head. Nonetheless, the player won't be able to stop laughing at his wonderful jokes.The personalities of the Colors are not particularly complicated, and are mostly covered in the section about gameplay above. There are certain characters later in the game worth mentioning, but spoiling the nature of these characters would not be fair to would-be players.While the characters are quite endearing, I can't give this section more than 6/10. There is little in the way of character development, and there isn't a lot of character variation.Controls: (4/10)Dark Souls: Prepare To Dye Edition was ported from the Nintendo Wii to PC, and as a port it does have some issues. The original game relied heavily on the Wiimote's motion control for the painting parts of the game, and this was only awkwardly replaced with a system using the mouse and keyboard on PC.It's difficult to play the game as intended on PC, and many blame the rushed release of the PC version for this. There are mods to fix the controls, but, despite this, I can't really give the game more than a 4/10 for the controls as they are by default. While the developers did have a difficult job porting a motion control game to the PC, they should have taken their time to properly implement the controls, rather than rushing the port like they did.Graphics (7/10)As I already mentioned, the game was ported from the Nintendo Wii, and the port is less than ideal. This can also be seen in the graphics, as the game doesn't support resolutions a PC player would consider acceptable. While this too can be fixed with mods, it should still be considered a problem with the port.Resolutions aside, the game itself is absolutely gorgeous. The haunting and simplistic beauty of the monochrome world is only surpassed by the gorgeous and vibrant landscapes that result from restoring color to the world. While the designs of the characters are significantly more simplistic by comparison, they suit the overall atmosphere of the game. In many ways they resemble characters from a children's picture book.Despite the issues with resolutions, I give the graphics a 7/10. The low resolution makes the game seem significantly older than it is, but even with this handicap the game looks gorgeous. With mods it might be one of the most beautiful titles on Steam.Sound (8/10)From Software is well known for its upbeat and catchy tunes, and Prepare to Dye is certainly no exception to this rule. In the monochrome world, the music is somber, but as color is restored to the world, the music grows livelier and more colorful as well. Once color is fully restored, the music gives you a happy sense of accomplishment. It's like an auditory representation of the canvas Adriano restored to life.The voice acting is a bit cheesy, however. The stereotypical Italian accents of Adriano and Francesco get more endearing once you get used to it, but the fact that the Colors and the other NPCs have standard American accents is a bit off-putting.That said, the voice acting can't pull down the overall sound score too much, as dialogue is not very important in Prepare to Dye. The music speaks more for the game than the voices do, and so I give the game an 8/10 for sound.Conclusion (7/10)Overall I give this game a 7/10. While it has many issues, it's a gorgeous classic made by a beloved game developer. I highly recommend giving it a try if you enjoy painting and art in general.

content:
ry 22
												Dark Souls is easily one of the best games I’ve ever played. Although advertised as a game for “masochists only”, I believe anyone can enjoy this game once they gain a good understanding of how the game works. It doesn’t hold your hand, it doesn’t give you many breaks, and it tries to punish you in every way possible. But pushing through the difficulty is well worth it, trust me. Underneath all the pain is a great and engaging game, that relies on good awareness, and patience above all else.The fantasy setting is one of a kind, rich with history and characters that made me feel part of the world. From very early on, I wanted to discover everything and travel everywhere. I always had choices of where I went, and what I wanted to do. Whether it be farming for weapons/souls/crafting materials, or continuing with the normal progression.The multiplayer of Dark Souls is perhaps one of the most interesting parts of the game. Relying on temporarily working with or against other players for short periods of time. Your single player adventure could be interrupted by an invading player, or aided by a friendly player at almost any point. It makes things particularly exciting as you never know what to expect. With comparison to the sequel games in the Dark Souls series, this first game is much less user friendly in terms of fast travelling, inventory management, and general multiplayer features, but it’s still a solid foundation from which the next games were able to grow from.Overall there isn’t much I can complain about Dark Souls. It’s a game I will always come back to because it’s just that good. Don’t be put off by the difficulty because once you know how to overcome it, I promise you’ll fall in love with this game.

content:
er 23, 2013
												Dark Souls is a hard game at first. It's oppresive, it's relentless, it's punishing and it won't hold your hand. You will be confused, and you WILL die. So prepare to die.Yet, as you progress through the game, you'll get the hang of it. After dying time and time again you'll learn how to tell if an enemy is going to attack you and how powerful that attack will be. You'll learn faster routes to get to your objective. And you'll learn to detach yourself from the souls you get. You WILL lose them. The point isn't to constantly grind - the point is to learn. And while a couple hundreds souls will be an awful lot during early game, by the end you can farm tens thousands of them in a couple of minutes.Take your time, be patient. It's mostly about the journey, and the elation you'll feel when overcoming the obstacles - the insurmountable odds against you, the unbreakable barrier. You'll die and then you'll learn and then you will achieve victory.So Praise the Sun!

content:
18
												Once I was in Kansas City and stopped in at a restaurant called The Hereford House.  I ordered a steak.  It was 24 ounces and about 3 inches thick.  It was perfectly cooked...somehow not bloody and not over done.  It was perfectly marbled.  It was absolutely delicious.If video games were steaks, then Dark Souls would be the one I described above.Even after all the years and all the newer (not better) souls games, and all the immitators, there's nothing like the original Dark Souls.  It lets you choose different paths of advancement and each path is - maybe not equally powerful - but equally viable.  There are many ways to kill the bosses.  Any of them which result in a dead boss is the correct way.  And it is very satisfying to play one of the hardest games ever made and still find new and different ways to make it look easy.Its not going to be easy your first play through.  Don't care who you are or how many games you've played.  But after the 5th time you've done it all, you'll start to understand what mistakes to avoid.  And you still won't be bored fighting the same bosses you've fought at least 5 (and probably more like 20) times before.Pros:  It's really a unique game which pits you against tough bosses and even random trash mobs that can ruin your day if you aren't on your game.Cons: I can't really think of any except to say that the console port is a console port.  You really must use a controller.  Yeah, you can configure mouse and keyboard... but use a controller if you don't want to hate life and burn your own house down in frustration.Normally I review things in a more clinical way.  But it wouldn't do this game justice.  If you want to see if you've really got what it takes to play a game designed to be hard, play this game.  Other games use the 'look hard, play easy' design paradigm.  That's fine.  Not every game should make you want to cry in frustration as a 250 pound grown man.  But if you  have to know if you're good enough as a gamer - there's no where else you need to look than Dark Souls.One last thing - Prepare to Die has extra content. It's not really as good as the original.  It's good, don't get me wrong.  But the bosses drift more to the 'cheap' side rather than the genuinely hard side.  So if you need to save a few bucks, skip Prepare to Die and you'll still get the experience.

content:
y 21
												What's there to say? This game is legendary!This is a masterpiece of our gaming age.It's certainly not for everyone. It's a love or hate. More like: you hate it but you grow to like it, even though you still hate it often. And it's bloody hard. At first ;)Let's start at the beginning, even if there's already a new niche made-up game genre called "souls-like", essentially this game is a 3D metroidvania fantasy adventure arpg game. It really is just that.What's so unique about it you ask? Well it takes "not holding your hand" concept to the extreme, freedom in its true sense, meaning - you don't understand ♥♥♥♥ and you don't know where to go and what to do! A true adventure!It's hard and unpredictable, it's pure exploration in its base meaning, you explore how world works, what's around the corner, what the heck is that giant thing is (followed by "You're dead"), what happens if this and "OH SHI.. I shouldn't have done that". Unfortunately it makes the plot "hard to get", it's weird at first to milk NPCs for dialogues and discovering the world through... spells' descriptions?... but it gets addictive after you're hooked, trying to find out why that boss is like that and drops what he drops or noticing the link between some enemies present in different locations etc. Exciting for those who like that kind of thing.And what about the main thing here - Combat?! Well it's AWESOME!The combat system is what makes Souls games so great. At first you hate it so much, you can't survive simple enemies, not mentioning the big bosses (the small ones are even worse).But then you learn it bit by bit and start to enjoy it. And there's lots to discover because: Lots of weapon types, different move sets Unique and Boss weapons with unique perks Weight and Poise system, which seriously affects battle Parry and Riposte system (also backstabbing), hard to master but rewarding Shield or Roll. There's no evasion stat or random chances, you learn to roll or leash out your (tower) shield, IF you can wield it ;) Lots of rings, each greatly affecting various aspects Mix and match left and right arms separately and several slots/sets to switch between Magic, Miracles, Pyromancy: wide array of magic skills to specialize or add to main buildAnd that's only combat, add these Pros to the bunch and you got yourself a prize: Non-linear gameplay, no hand holding if you don't want it Unique co-op and pvp system Various covenants (you can call them guilds or alliances for better understanding) for PvE rewards or PvP action & else Unique style, world and enemies. Environment is freaky but interesting. Somewhat unique levelling system and skills system Skill based. It's a common challenge in Souls games to beat the game without levelling a single time.It still has it's own cons of course, some harsh ones, because it's THE legendary Dark Souls ;D You will die a lot, but it's not the end. Be prepared to fail and get up. Your nerves will most likely be tested and even messed up. A lot of adrenaline too. Story is hard to find and hard to follow at times. Invasion system is a big turn-off for some in an already unforgiving game. It's an interesting system but it ♥♥♥♥s you up often. There's always offline mode though. You don't understand ♥♥♥♥. Trial and error approach. It's a debatable pro-or-con. Hard to get hooked from your first session. Many of us have started this game multiple times before really getting to love it. It's this game quirk and a part that makes it great in fact.So there you have it. Dark Souls. Such a game, it's a love-hate relationship in it's bliss.I call it a BDSM of gaming sometimes. It's a queen dominatrix at that. But it's greatness obliterates any unnerving breakdown you will have while playing. You WILL start it up again even after ragequitting. Believe me :)So if you're not afraid of challanges and tough games, if you are ready to test your gaming skills and not just relax and sit back while playing after a hard day. This is worth it!P.S. the community can be harsh with comments like condescending "git gud" and "this is dark souls", but be sure there are lots of us who likes and wants to help by word and co-op on the forums/discussions, lots of friendly people.  P.P.S. what's more interesting the online in this game is still very much alive and kicking!

13, 2014
												You won't like this game. Don't buy it. You will die repeatedly. The game will actively punish you for every misstep, forcing you to swim upstream, suffer, and learn from your failures. It will eat your soul, and spit it back onto your mangled, decaying corpse. Over and over again. And then it will sit back on it's throne, waiting for you to come back for more.It's also the most rewarding, challenging, and hands down the best game I've ever played. This is a masterpiece that only a fortunate, and patient few, will ever get to fully experience.Praise the sun!

content:
0, 2015
/!\DON'T PLAY THIS GAME WITHOUT A CONTROLLER/!\/!\MAKE SURE YOU HAVE DSFIX[blog.metaclassofnil.com]/!\Time to complete 40hrs+
Time to 100% ~110hrs
Difficulty: [■■■□□] - Challenging
Genre: Action-RPG, Die&Retry
With a game of this caliber, it's hard to know where to begin...I could go on for eons about how awesome and well-made this game is, so I'll try to keep it short hereThroughout the game, Hidetaka Miyasaki clearly shows he is a master of Game Design and Storytelling-First off, the very few bad points this game has (Let's face it, it was a very bad PC port)Terrible Mouse and Keyboard controlsFPS cap without DSFIX[blog.metaclassofnil.com]  (which is a mod that pretty much makes the game all round prettier)Bad Anti-Aliasing (without DSFIX)Multiplayer broken (without DSFIX)No Anti-Cheat at allAnd now onto a very succinct list of the good stuff:GameplayVery challenging situationsIncredibly rewardingEnormously diverse items, with a lot of different and viable playstylesSuprisingly fair (under NG+2, and except for a single boss)Level DesignYou can walk from almost any area to another, a lot of shortcuts and interconnections are scattered between themThe setting is very different in every area, and goes very well with the theme that is expressed through itComplex and very epic Boss FightsThe enemy placement is incredibly well thought and fluidThe various mechanisms have effects than can clearly be measured and have an actual impact on the gameLoreVery, very richIncredibly deepRidiculously good Character and Boss designNot linear, not clearly establishedEvery single thing in the game contributes to it in one way or anotherMultiplayerEmbed into the game, no unnecessary interfacesVery fluidVery high skillcapAgain, lots of playstyles possibleAtmosphereGreat ParallaxesGreat LandscapesThemed and very different zones (From the Realm of the gods to the Crystal Caves, through the Cities, Ruins, Sewers, and Mushroom Stashes)Although very scarce, the music is very pleasant and goes well with the areaCharacters, Merchants, Foes and Monsters in general are incredibly diverse and correspond perfectly to their area/zoneForever an insanely pleasant game

content:
0, 2014
												After 48 grueling hours of playtime, I had finally beaten Sif, the Four Kings, Seath The Scaleless, and Nito. I climbed down past the bog, in my noble sorcerers cloth, with boots and gauntlets of gold metal salvaged from Ornstien's soul it's self. Lighting the path in front of me with only the glint of my estoc and the afterglow of magic, when the path before me lighted up by it's self, a orange, firey glowIN FRONT OF ME, sat OVER FOURTY kangaroo/dinosaur hybrids, a field of lava that could only be traversed by walking on it, and no bonfire in sight for over 5 minutes of travel time through the ruined city. I had to lose some weight to travel at my fastest, and I took off my gauntlets and replaced my boots with common shoes. I put on my lava ring, and snuck across the side of the monsterous area, constantly having to find a dry rock to heal myself on.And then promptly got sat on, instantly died, and had to restart, having lost all my experience points and money. This finally broke me, and all of my normal senses vanished, and my stubbernness was replaced, not by greater determination, but conceeding to follow the rules of the game instead.I got entirely naked, put on a hat bigger than my already barreled chest, a dinky knight's shield I had picked up 8 levels back, and ♥♥♥♥ING SPRINTED AS FAST AS I COULD. This morphed in to twenty minutes of speedily scouting the area ahead, then using it to formulate a plan to continue going fast enough to dodge every enemy attack. At one point, a friend messaged me with a simple link that lead to a mashup between "Escape the City" from Sonic the Hedgehog, and the ghostbusters theme.This proved to be a great theme, and I pushed forward, eventually finding the bed of chaos.This lead to two more hours of sprinting with nothing but a gigantic hat, my naked fat black body slapping across dinosaurs as I body'd them out of the way, and sprinted in to the boss with my magically enchanted shield, and then eventually killing the main boss by doing 6 damage to it by hitting it with my staff. I literally jumped from my desk, raised my hands in the air and screamed "YES!", as my headphones ripped out of the jack and my speakers came alive, in the middle of a solo between the ghostbusters theme and sonic the hedgehog yelling in his ever so annoying voice "FOLLOW ME, SET ME FREE, TRUST ME AND WE CAN ESCAPE FROM THE CITY"Would I recommend this game?I can't imagine how to describe the experience. It was wonderful and yet I truely wish, hope, PRAY, that I never experience it again. My thumb rating would be 4 out of 2 thumbs cut off.Since steam doesn't abide by this, thumbs up for solaire. He's a pretty cool guy.

content:
30, 2016
												tl;dr --> game good. game not hard. game punishing. you like punishing? get game.This is a very poor port of a very good game.Luckily there are a couple of fixes around that make it play like an actual pc game; check the pinned threads on the game's discussions to find everything you need.By now you probably heard of Dark Souls only through statements like"omg dis gaem is like so hard i died liek 50 times in teh tutoriel lol xd"and thanks to that the sequels have been advertised with difficulty being the main attraction, but the game never really focuses on being hard for the sake of being hard: it just doesn't hold your hand, at all, and that's why it feels so good to overcome the obstacles the game throws at you, because from start to finish it is entirely your own victory... unless you read a walkthrough, then shame on you, you filthy casul.So what can you expect from this game?Well they don't call it the "Prepare To Die™ Edition" for nothing, lolPrepare to die a lot, not because of the game, but because you suck at it; dying punishes you putting you back at the last bonfire you rested at, respawning all enemies, and taking away all your precious souls you have in possession at the time of death (you need those to level up). You have one chance to get them back at the spot you died at, but if you die again before recovering them, they're gone forever. But as long as you don't lose your experience, your patience and you don't give up, dying matters very little: no matter how many souls you lose, each time you go back you're stronger... not your character, but you as a player.Prepare for an excellent combat system with a very good feel to the melee combat in particular, forget Skyrim and its hundreds of weapons that are all reskins of the same one, here weapons have all different movesets, range, properties... and most of all they still hit the enemy even if you don't point the crosshair at them (yes I'm still looking at Skirim smh); all attacks have an animation that you can't cancel (unless you get hit) so you're committed to every strike, you can't treat it like a hack'n'slash and start hacking'n'slashing left and right, that will get you killed fast.Prepare to have no map... so you better remember how to get back to that door you skipped because you had no key to open it. You will almost never feel the need of a map however, thanks to the clever level design and the fact each area looks unique.Prepare to have no story spoonfed to you... as in, little to no cutscenes showcasing big events. Nothing much happens in this "story" because the "story" already happened: all the epic fights, the shiny castles, the people smiling... they're all gone. You have no idea what happened when you arrive here, but you can piece together information from item descriptions and locations and NPC dialogues to get an idea of what it was like before and how it's come to this. Or, you can also not do it if you don't want, and complete the game without really knowing why... up to you.Prepare for silence... only boss battles and a few very special places have music, and it's 100% Motoi Sakuraba goodness.Prepare to be alone... but not quite... multiplayer works in a very interesting way, blending together singleplayer and multiplayer seamlessly. In short, coop is temporary and limited to an area, you can "summon" other players into your gameworld and fight together, until the area boss dies... or one of you dies.Prepare for pvp... yes, in the same way you can summon players, other players can also enter your world without your consent, and really ruin your day. Before you get scared, don't worry, there are areas where multiplayer is restricted, and playing in hollow form will prevent any multiplayer interaction anywhere.Prepare to hate the game at first... but expect to sooner or later fall in love with it... they all do in the end...Prepare to Praise the Sun... you'll know when you meet him.

content:
ber 30, 2016
												Dark Souls is a game I avoided for years based on reputation. I'll admit it, I was afraid of a game this challenging. I started and gave up on Dark Souls a few times, but my most recent attempt had me falling head over heels in love. This is one of the best RPGs I've ever played, and one that offers so much more to it than simply difficulty. In a sea of games that assume you're an idiot, this title wants you to explore, fail, and succeed in ways never spelled out directly. The PC version needs several mods to bring it up to the standards one would expect performance wise, but in spite of the glitches and oddities Dark Souls is one of the premier titles available, and a game that is well and truly timeless.

content:
y 18, 2015
DISCLAIMER: I have never played Demon Souls, and I play Dark Souls 2 (See my review) before I played this.  I was waiting for GFWL to be gone.Onward.FIRST IMPRESSIONS: After playing DS2, my first thought on DS1 was "Wow this game looks bad".  I thought it was grainy and ugly and honestly had a hard time.  A friend recommended I get DSFIX and some other tweaks and the game looked and ran much better after that.This game is NOT DS2, I learned that pretty quickly.  I was a cheesy ranged magic user in DS2 and in this one, I hated magic right off the bat, it was so slow.  I was forced to learn melee play more than I had before.  Man did I start to finally learn some mechanics I missed even after an entire play-through of DS2.  I learned how to properly roll and dodge, how to properly parry and back-stab.  Fun stuff.  I mean I had done it before, but then crutched out on ranged combat so never had to master it.Not to say I did not use ranged in this game.  I just used a Bow to pull certain enemies and kill others.  More fun than magic.CONTROL: Again, I am doing this backwards since I played DS2 first.  Once you have it down, the game controls well.  It seems a lot cleaner than DS2, tighter.  I did not seem to get "cheap" shotted as much.  If you played DS2 first like me, you'll be fine.COMBAT: Fluid, scary!!  The enemies hit HARD, all of them, and as I said above, the control is key to getting good at the combat.  Ranged piercing hits are kind of overpowered so get a weapon that does that to ease things up a bit if you are having problems.The bosses in this game I had heard were hard.  Some of them to be honest simply kicked the living crap out of me so often it is embarrassing.  I am a slow learner but I don't get frustrated.  Watch the boss mechanics, move around a lot, and be SMART with your blocks and stamina and all bosses become much easier.  I HATED the Stray Demon and all things like him (@&^*%#@&^% those things).STORY: As with DS2, I did not follow the story much.  This game is all about fighting for me.  I thought DS2 had more interesting characters that followed you through the game more though.  Quite possible I missed something though.WORLD: Holy hell did I get confused by this world.  I had no clue where to go first, what to do, etc.  I felt less hand held and directed than I was in DS2.  I frequently went to areas that were WAY too hard for me (hollow Catacombs and Tomb!) way before I should be there.  I found myself repeating areas over and over to just practice combat and build up souls for weapon improving more that anything for a long timeEventually I learned how the entire world links together VERY well, and it is all connected and loops together brilliantly.  The fact that you can't warp around right from the start (You can later... way later for me ;P) is actually a blessing in disguise.OTHER: I put 120+ hrs into this game before I finally beat it.  If this review is anything like my DS2 one.  Someone will tell me how much I suck.  Well, so what if I suck.  I had 120+ hours of fun and have put in 20+ more since.I would love to see a "Collection" edition that had Demon Souls so I could play that one.  Bloodborne will make me buy a PS4 simply because it is a "Dark Souls" type game.I loved this game, I loved part 2 (I play to play a melee only DS2 run now ;P)Go play it.

content:
er 28, 2013
												Dark Souls is one of my absolute favorite games of the generation.It features a giant interconnected world with tons of hidden areas to explore. The game is challenging but not overwhelming so. Dying is a necessary aspect of learning the game but once you get the hang of it, progression can offer a very strong sense of accomplishment. The combat is rock solid and skill based with each of the weapons having their very own unique move-set. Dark Souls has RPG elements and an extremely unique multiplayer component. It's set up as a single player game but you can occasionally see the ghosts of other players which can offer hints on where (or where not to go). Players can also leave notes for one another and can be summoned to help with the many bosses. On the other hand, they can also invade your world and attempt to kill you. Dark Souls also offers plenty of replayability. It's not uncommon to spend 50 hours or so on your initial playthrough and once you complete the game, it has a New Game+ where everything becomes increasingly difficult. I've played through the game four times on Xbox and it never gets old.Just make sure you play the game with a controller as it isn't very keyboard and mouse friendly.For a more indepth and thorough review, check out my video:

content:
ber 23, 2016
 Difficulty Let's get the obvious out of the way. Is this game challenging? Yes. Is this game hard for new players? Yes. Is this game impossible? Absolutely not. This game has a reputation for being a very hard game, sometimes being dubbed "The Hardest Game Ever." I will tell you right now that while the game is hard in the beginning, especially for new players, it can easily be learned. It is just another game in which the level designers introduce escalating challenges for the player to face. The game starts off showing you the basic controls (attacking, dodging, healing etc.) but those who pay attention can notice that the game is slowly introducing the player to how certain challenges must be approached (fighting one target, fighting multiple target, fighting ranged targets etc.). The golden rule is to watch your surroundings, and watch your enemies. You will be able to figure things out for yourself, because though the game may not tell you outright, it does show you the ropes before it throws you into the fire. Of course you may get stuck in some parts and there is no shame in looking at a guide. I did as well in the beginning. But before you do, look around the world and look for places you have not seen before. If the area is new, and the enemies are not too hard to fight, then you are going the right way. Gameplay This game is very satisfying. If you are new to Dark Souls then you will die, very often. But that is the whole point of the game so do not feel discouraged. This game will be hard in some parts, and you will come across an obstacle that seems impossible to defeat. But when you accomplish the task, and you will, you will feel amazing. You are also given a wide variety of weapons and armor to use. Each weapon has a specific move set that fulfills some task. When you find the armor and weapons that fit your play style, upgrade them and have fun. Weapons are another aspect of this game that are very satisfying. The weapons, ranging from practical to ridiculous, all have a weighted feeling to them. You don't just blindly swing a sword around like Skyrim, there is timing involved. When you get a hit in and you watch the enemies health go down, you will feel like a million dollars. Story Along with the difficulty, the story also has a reputation. Much like the gameplay, the story is left up to the player for the most part. You are given an intro cinematic which lays down the history of the world. But once you are in the game proper the story is really only told through NPC dialogue and item descriptions. This makes the story a little bit of a mystery, you being the one who takes in information and clues to piece together the more in depth history of the world. Even when you have finished this game you can spend days watching videos of people explaining what happened in events before the game, and events that are happening in the game. Something as simple as armor next to a bonefire, or a suspicious item in someones treasure chest can open up entire stories. Levels The entire world is seamlessly connected. Except for a few areas that require special passage, the different areas are interconnected and it is possible to walk from each and every one without having a single loading screen. This helps  make the world seem more alive and grand, especially when, in some cases you are able to see one area from another. The visuals are also amazing. Whether it be from the top of a mountain peak or through a lush forest the atmosphere will certainly drag you in. However in some parts of the game, the framerate will go down drastically. Multiplayer I don't believe Multiplayer was the main focus of this game, however it is present. Online play shows in the form of covenants, different groups that fulfill some role. Some covenants like the Warriors of Sunlight are available to help you out, while others like the Darkwraiths will join your game with the main goal of killing you. These days, the Darkwraiths are the only ones around, and connecting with people to COOP is nearly impossible. It has been patched but in my experience, online play is not very common. DS Fix DS Fix is a mod that I highly suggest players to get. One of the biggest problems with Dark Souls for some people is the fact that the game is locked at 30 FPS. This mod unlocks the framerate allowing one to reach 60 fps and solve some of the visual issues that people experience. Cons I highly suggest this game and I find it Overwhelmingly positive, however here are some things that one should keep in mind.-Framerate is locked at 30, and in some places will go even lower making the game hard to play. Use DS Fix and this problem should be remedied-Near the end of the game, some areas seem rushed in their design. One major boss in particular is notable for being rather lazy, and requires more luck than skill in order to fight. This is something the entire community will agree is the lowest point of the game-Online play is not handled well. Though it is unique, you will have a better chance of being invaded by an enemy than you are being able to play with a friend. Though the strongest element of Dark Souls is it's single player so this should not be a problem-This game can really only be played with a controller. If you do not have one I suggest waiting on buying this game until you can get one. There is a keyboard and mouse setting but it is very difficult to play with. Final Word Dark Souls is truly a unique experience for any player. I've seen people put off by the difficulty at first and then eventually return to it hooked (This happened to me). If you are a fan of story and lore, this game is rich in it's atmosphere, world building, and unique presentation. Gameplay fluctuates from a fast panicked pace to slow anxious one. There are a variety of weapons that one can pick up and use to fit their play style. Overall this game is an experiment in determination. Every challenge can be completed and every enemy can be defeated. If you have learned the elements of the game, and have adapted to its rules, you will succeed. I highly recommend this game.Good Luck, and don't you dare go Hollow.

content:
ry 4
												It's insane how much content they could fit in the game. Sure, the texture quality might not be the greatest (but take note that the game itself is from 2011) but the level design is TOP NOTCH. In some areas you just need to take a breather and take a look around. For example in Anor Londo, the view is gorgeous as the hints on the ground suggest.This game has an incredible way to tell a story through the environment. You won't be bugged with long cutscenes of certain incidents, you'll just hear of them through the NPCs, like merchants.The game creates an atmoshpere that you'll find hard to drag yourself out of. I myself found it difficult to stop thinking of the new areas I could find in the future, hours after closing the game. And so, the game kept luring me back in.Sure. The game is difficult to someone jumping into the specific playstyle-genre for the first time. But still, after a lot of trial and error, beating a single boss fight after a half an hour learning its attack patterns, success feels rewarding.In conclusion this game is a gem worth the praise it gets. I myself would rate it a solid 9/10 (would've given 10 if it wasn't for the clumsy pc port, which could've been improved a bit).

content:
r 18, 2014
												Don't get greedy. This is the golden rule of Dark Souls, and the key to your success or failure playing it.Story-wise, the game is deceptively simple. At first appearance there is little information given, you are told almost nothing and given a surprisingly large world to fight in. But this is what a lot of people love about Dark Souls - you get out of it what you put into it. Dig a little bit below the surface and there is actually a vast lore with tons of information, detective work and speculation for you to piece together if you are perceptive and observant. Item descriptions tell an entire world's worth of details, occasional lines of NPC small talk reveal facts that can expand the lore by surprising amounts, details in the landscape give inferences to greater world events. The only times you are directly told something important you can be sure as hell the tellers have an angle they are pushing and it probably isn't the full picture.World design-wise, you have a surprisingly large stage to explore and, most importantly, it *feels* like you are exploring a massive land in a fading world rather than a set of different levels. Just about everywhere in the game is interconnected and criss-crosses with other areas in some way, you can walk from one area to another and then look back and see exactly where you came from and look forwards and know you'll eventually get there (and sometimes even see tiny orange player messages in the distance, which is a nice touch). The shortcuts exemplify this, it genuinely feels like everything is one large castle.Mechanics-wise, see the first sentence. This is a game of patience and cat-and-mouse baiting. Lure enemies into one-on-one combat, don't get flanked, learn when to tank and when to evade, plan your attack movements, use everything and anything to your advantage. Death has little meaning as everything lost on death can be infinitely regained, so it becomes a learning mechanism rather than a punishment. Sometimes the lesson may be 'go elsewhere' or 'try a different method.'Character building can vary greatly. Do you want to be a heavy knight with a massive weapon, or a dexterous archer, or a tactical mage? The beginning class choice is essentially meaningless in the long run, it just determines what gear you start with and gives you some stats you'd have even with a different class (eg you'll probably end up putting some points into faith so for the heal miracle regardless of your build). You can effectively beat the game with almost any playstyle or build, though some are definitely easier than others.Use humanity at a bonfire to un-hollow yourself and you can summon other players to help you fight areas and bosses at the risk of being invaded and killed by someone else. There are also NPCs who can be summoned and even invade you, which is nice if you're offline, though there are sometimes conditions for summoning them such as them having been in the previous boss fight or them invading you and defeating them.There are some spots it suffers from poor design, let's be honest. These are generally not so much in terms of enemies or player options but in terms of terrain and meshes - the Great Hollow is a good example of this, sometimes you will go flying down and to the side to your death because god forbid you touched the wrong angled mesh despite having had an apparently clear angle to your destination. The Bed of Chaos is especially obnoxious with this, but the less said about that the better. The Painted World doesn't mesh with the rest of the game very well, it's more or less where the devs put half-finished ideas that they didn't want to throw out, which is a pity because information on the stage itself and boss are very interesting but rather undeveloped and could have been expanded on much more (I was especially disappointed that I couldn't return the doll to its owner). Most of the game has excellent level design, however, the exceptions to this are only exceptions and not the rule.I am not skilled enough at pvp to really go into it, look elsewhere for an analysis on that. I will say that in my experience pvp has been annoyingly full of longer-range bleed weapons and little else in terms of variety, lag is also very much present and will lead to you missing when you clearly connected and getting hit or backstabbed when you were clear across the area.All in all, brilliant game that you will probably quit the first time you play it then come back to much later and eventually enjoy. Takes time to 'get it' which can be considered both a major weakness of it and a massive strength to it. Just about every bit of progress you've made (both in-game and in understanding/learning the game) is a result of your own effort and accomplishment, very little is given to you so again you get out of it what you put into it.Note that due to the devs self-admittedly being inexperienced at PC porting, there are some native issues. These are mostly fixed by getting DSfix and configuring it for whatever needs to be tweaked for your setup. Edit: since it was updated to run off Steam directly some parts of the DSfix may need to be altered or disabled to get it working properly.

number of helpful: 46 of 53 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
er 18, 2013
												I like Dark Souls, it's not for everyone, but you might like it too. You probably don't need me to tell you that Dark Souls has a reputation for being balls hard, and while it's not an unmerited reputation it has more to do with the game deciding that the player can do without certain conveniences rather than dicking you over. The new XCOM is a game that ♥♥♥♥♥ you over by letting your squadmates perma-die, roguelikes often ♥♥♥♥ you over by starting the game over when you die. Those are features added to make the game harder and while I have nothing wrong with either if they're implemented well, Dark Souls uses subtraction, which is a subtler bouquet. So modern gaming conveniences that are generally thought of as necessary for smooth gameplay have been thrown aside. So while I don't think the bosses in Dark Souls (which are generally regarded as being brutal) are tougher on paper than any other third-person action game of this type  (they don't take a ludicrous amount of damage, attack patterns aren't hard to learn) the game doesn't do you any favors in getting past them. When you die you don't immediately respawn at the start of the battle and have to work your way back, you can't load up on enough health items to forgo learning the boss's patterns.Playing Dark Souls is like giving up your smart phone for a day. "Oh wow, it is possible to exist without being connected to eleven different social networks while being in perpetual contact with hunderds of people!" I'm not saying I want every game to wantonly cut the fat like Dark Souls, but it's nice to know that I don't need my hand held, that I can be expected to figure out a crafting system on my own, that I can be expected to discover things without any prompting. It's all very empowering.I also think Dark Souls makes some smart choices to distinguish itself from similar RPGs. First off it doesn't feature an open world. I'm not a huge fan of open worlds. I think it's more challenging to craft a small gameworld where every step is deliberately placed, every nook and cranny there for a reason, than to make a big ♥♥♥ map and then scatter a few waypoints even across it. Every thing you find and every where you go in Dark Souls feels like you figured out and uncovered rather than just being something you stumbled upon. Plus, if you get stuck in one direction and feel like exploring you know you're always going to find something new if you push along that path you were stuck at before. You're never going to waste your time because the developer didn't drop something cool where you decided to explore.Dark Souls also handles weapons and armor brilliantly. There are very few inately bad weapons and none that so completely out-class others that they make other options pointless. You find a weapon with a moveset you like and then, with upgrades through the crafting system you can take that weapon all the way to the final boss. It's a perfect way to defeat the RPG trope of, reach new town, buy new weapon/armor set, fight boss.Of course Dark Souls is a game that requires dedication and patience. Not everyone will have the time and attention to dedicate 80+ hours to get through. If you do though it's a unique and satisfying experience.

content:
er 30, 2015
												Heads up: this is not a review on the actual content of the game, this is a review on how good of a PC port this is in comparison to the original verison of the game.This is a very good game, but unfortunately I can't recommend it because this port is the absolute worst port I've ever seen of any game in my life. The main problems I notice is that the keyboard controls make absolutely no sense at all and that the button tutorials at the beginning are actually for an Xbox controller, which I was not using so they did not help me at all. I can understand that it's highly recommended to use a controller, but since I'm playing this on a PC I should be able to use a keyboard if that's what I prefer or if it's all I have. The keyboard controls could have easily been done better. I pressed every single key and not a single one of them opened up the main game menu. I had to force quit the game just so I could get back to the title screen and the options menu. And again, it just looks extemely lazy to reuse the tutorials from the Xbox version when someone is playing with a keyboard on a PC.The other main thing I have to complain about with this port is the performance issues. I experience constant framerate drops while playing that make this game almost as unplayable as the controls do. However, I have heard that basically everyone who buys this game for PC has the same problems, and as a result there are mods out there that fix these problems and--I have to admit--actually seem to make this version perform better than the console version. But am I the only one who thinks that it's a major flaw when a game needs to be modded just to be playable?All I can end with is: if you own a Playstation 3 or an Xbox 360, you would be saving yourself a tremendous amount of trouble by just getting the console version of this game. I have played this game on 360 and the controls are great and the performance is flawless (with the exception of the notorious Blighttown framerate).TL;DR  This game is unplayable without modding it to improve performance and using a controller. If you don't own a controller and/or don't want to mod the game, then you're better off getting the console version if you own a PS3 or 360.EDIT: Calling this port unplayable may not be entirely accurate and a little harsh. I personally went out and purchased an Xbox controller and spent an entire afternoon modding the game, and now I have to say I find it better than the console version of the game. But I still have to say that this game will be VERY difficult for anyone to enjoy in its default state. I still cannot for the life of me set up the keyboard controls in a way that is comfortable or at least not confusing (also still never found a key for the menu in the default controls). Also, I don't know if I'm in the majority or the minority with the performance problems. Most people I've talked to or heard talk about this port highly recommend the DSfix mod to make the game run more smoothly. So this is a common problem but not a problem that every single person who downloads the game experiences.After tweaking the game myself I think I can say that if you're someone who doesn't mind using a controller and possibly going out of your way to install a mod or two, then I recommend this game to you 110% (assuming of course you know what Dark Souls is and what you're getting yourself into). But I am still going to leave this as a negative review, because what I'm reviewing here is how the game is in its present default state, not how it is with a controller and a bit of modding. And frankly, in its default state this port is just...bad.

content:
er 24, 2016
												Nominated for the "Just 5 more minutes" award.What can I say? The whole game is based around just five more minutes. Whether it's just five more minutes until I get back to the boss, just five more minutes until I get to the next bonfire checkpoint, or just five more minutes(hours) until I give up.Dark souls is both a challenging and methodical approach to the modern day dungeon crawler, and plays similar to an action RPG. Areas are intricately crafted with beautiful scenery, and every enemy and item has a purpose and reason for being there. So whether it's because you decided to walk the wrong direction at Firelink Shrine or maybe dealing with the archers of Anor Londo, there's always something there to make you hate yourself a bit more in this game, just because you know that the mistakes are all on you. The 'Open' world is also a nice change of pace from its PS3 predecessor Demon Souls, and feels atmospherically better than its sequel, Dark Souls II, despite a several flaws such as a 30fps lock.There are many who enjoy a challenge, but even more who are turned off by it. However, with some effort and habit breaking, even an unexperienced gamer would be able to enjoy this game. The game has gone on sale as low as 5 USD, but it is well worth the full 20 USD price.

												*Refunded*It's not a bad game... I am just bad at it. So bad in fact that it is not even remotely fun for me. I basically would die, learn the strat a bit more, die again, learn the strat a bit better just to die again. I understand this is a game of pefect timing and masterful skill, I just apparently lack either. I AM NOT SAYING DO NOT PURCHASE THIS GAME. I am just saying I personally did not enjoy the trial and error formula. I actually see the value and complexity to a game like this. It simply isn't for me. I am actually going to still give this a thumbs up, not because I enjoyed it but rather because I respect what the game accomplishes. Tight gameplay, a smart story, a beautiful atmosphere and of course a good challenge. Long story short if you like trial and error games that offer a high ammount of reward/accomplishment then you will likely love this. If you are looking for something you can pick up and play through with no hiccups then try something else.-Casey

ber 28, 2015
My experience on Day 1  - This should help you decide if you want to play!Today I played my first my first 5 or so hours of the game and I have to say.. it was a great experience. I purchased the game on the idea of a challenge and a skill cap that I would want to pop but that proves to be harder than I first thought.A friend starts talking to me on steam just as I see the first boss and tells me the joy that can come from Dark Souls. I listen and I quickly see what the game has to offer and I also notice that my friend will be my mentor through this experience. After just under 10 lives I manage to kill the first boss and arive at Lordan. After speaking to a guy who seems to know more about myself than I do, I realise that the goal of the game is to reach a destination of some sort.I then go forward and find that I must defeat pairs of skeletons... who are overpowerd and after 10 or so lives I realise I need to do something different. I go down there and rush.. without even looking at the skeletons and see a shield. I die quickly after and the go back down to look for other items. By now I have realised how the soul system of the game works and that if I die I must retreve my souls from the spot I have died. I level up my dexterity because that seems to be what I need and go for many more runs with each life teaching my more about the combat of the game.I start to give up alittle bit but then my guide (friend) replys after being afk. My question is "Am I doing something wrong" and proceed to tell him about the skeletons. He then replys with a quick tip, "Try seeking a plan B route". It hits me. I have been going the wrong direction the whole time. I quickly find a stair route that have much weaker enemies in it. My new weakness... grouped up enemies that attack shortly after one another while you are downed and/or recovering. Quickly I begin to realise that they must be seperated and try just that.2 Hours pass and countless lives go along with them. Keeping calm and learning from my mistakes and such. Finally I get to a tower-ish area, do you go up or down? I go up and walk along a bridge area. BOOM, a boss... much to powerful for my equipment and I. So I die... go back and choose to go down and am met with a boss. You know what happened... don't you?!~Day 1 - This game... its hard to believe it was made so long ago for something that wants to challenge you in such a way... and I love it!

												£20 for Dark Souls: Prepare to Die edition? That's what I thought while shopping in Asda one day, and so I picked up the phsyical edition of the game. After installing Microsft's DRM service, Games for Windows Live, and discovering the game didn't want to link to my Steam account, I started playing. While Dark Souls is an incredibly fun game, I just can't recommend it while it still has Games for Window's Live attached to it. After the service managed to delete my account, meaning I couldn't save my game, I decided to buy it on Steam in the sales so as to be able to actually have a save file. And guess what? The game still makes me use GfWL, and now the service is refusing to let me log in at all - meaning it will be impossible to ever save my game. Unless this is fixed, I'm going to have to wait until June 2014 (when Live is shut down - hurrah) before I can play a game I've bought twice. This is incredibly disappointing.

content:
er 7, 2013
												PRAISE THE SUN!If only I could be so grossly incandescent!Jolly co-operation!^^These quotes will be part of your life forever.The Demon's Souls and Dark Souls games are my favorite series this gen. They changed the way I look at ARPGs with the fantastic combat and the open worlds you can play within. The combat is just amazing with every weapon having different mechanics and animations so you can try tons of different styles of  gameplay from big swords to daggers to dual wielding to being a pokey turtle with a spear and giant shield.  Not just melee, but Pyromancy, Sorcery, and Miracles are available too with their wands and gloves and can all be used by every player if your skills are good enough. Don't forget to use the items too for some fun ways of attackign enemies like poison arrows and darts. This game is an RPG with a story that isn't spoon fed to you. This series tells a story through item descriptions and other obscure places. It is a world of lore that is found through reading items and very few cutscenes. You awaken in this world and everyone is just as crazy as you will feel. You upgrade your levels by collecting souls to increase your attributes, which allow you to wield more weapons and cast different magics. STamina is important. Very important. Don't skimp on it. This series introduced a fascinating online mechanic. While I like the messages and the blood stains more in Demon's Souls, Dark Souls still has them. Messages can be left from other players that can either help, or trick you into a death. These are all pre-written messages and you choose from a list for obvious reasons. Blood stains allow you to view how other explorers have died! Sometimes these are hilarious.The big online aspect , however is the PvP and the co-op it provides. If you have used Humanity to get into human form you can be INVADED by other players on the server at any time as long as you have not killed the area boss. "XXXXXX Has Invaded ....." starts the heart pumping immediately as you play cat and mouse while you search each other out. Ultimately one of you finds the other with a sneak attack, or you just make a friendly bow and start to circle each other for a one on one fight to the death! You can even have summoned phantoms help you out if you find their summon signs first to fell these invaders.The Co-op aspect works like the messages where summon signs are placed upon the ground and you can summon Blue Phantoms (other players) to help you through the area and ultimately defeat the boss. Dark Souls also introduced Covenants, which allow you to join mysterious groups within the world. Each group has different benefits for members. They will put you in a bullseye for more invaders, allow you to team up easier for co-op with friendly players, give you extra powers, and many more things. Several of these are available and can be joined when found and leaving another Covenant. While the online aspects are intriguing this game is at its heart a single player game. One that can be played with the threat of invasions by staying in Human form, or completely alone by playing offline, or as a Hollow. This game isn't a PvP game, while many will try to make it one. This edition does offer an Arena, however with the new DLC to play PvP as much as you want without having to search for players to invade in the world itself. The main way to play this is to think of it as a single player game with online elements. These online elements add to the difficulty as there is no AI that can give you the challenge that a human player can. These invasions are to put a kink in your exploration and make the world even more dangerous.The PC port graphically isn't the greatest, however. Most players have downloaded the mod named DSFix (search google) to help with some of the technical aspects of the game. Dark Souls has its own Nexus site and is completely compatible with the Nexus Mod Manager like the Elder Scrolls and Fallout games have, but these are mostly cosmetic as adding anythign that could impact other players would be illegal for an online experience. A bunch of other graphical upgrades are available as well as the ability to replace the gamepad buttons like to PS3 buttons for those of us that use a PS3 controller, and many other controller buttons are there too for peopel that like Logitech.This series is one that you should not miss. If you have a Playstation 3 try getting and playing Demon's Souls first, however as this has changed some of the gameplay a bit. My best surprise in gaming ever was Demon's Souls buying it on a whim the first week it came out. It is an epic adventure. I believe that the servers are actually still Live as well so you should be able to play online last I checked.

content:
er 13, 2013
												Dark Souls™: Prepare To Spend 3 Hours Modding And Troubleshooting Errors To Make It A Decent Port™ EditionBut after that, this game is delicious. It feels like the developers have been isolated from society for several years while making this game, and never had any idea of the standards that have been set in modern game development.The standards where button mashing is always a legitimate option, where the player's hand is held with constant instruction and navigational aid (even to the point where games play themselves), where there is no consequence for dying.This game is oblivious to all of that. The combat is extremely satisfying; complex and risky, without being overly convoluted. Button mashing WILL get you killed right away. Every weapon has its own moveset, handling, and attributes. You will die a lot. Success comes from learning the mechanics, attack animations, enemy AI, physics, and reasons behind your mistakes. It becomes the most fun thing ever and oh mah gawwwwd the boss designs are wicked intense, and environments are gorgeous and seamlessly intertwined. It's an open world where you can get lost and discover places "early", but there is no such thing as being underleveled. Your level means nothing, and you can complete many areas whether you upped your damage or not. It's all about what you can handle.I give this a Yes out of 10 rating. play play play play play play play play

content:
ry 10, 2014
												This is the game guys. Along with its predecessor Demon's Souls this game has become my favorite game of all time and even rivals games like The Legend of Zelda, Metroid, Metal Gear Solid, Okami and Mass Effect. Games that I hold dearly in my heart because they are special to me. If you have played Demon's Souls you will feel right at home. Like Demon's Souls, Dark Souls is an incredibly rewarding game.The story and lore is fascinating and deep even though the game is not very good at telling you these things.The combat in this game is top notch and the vast amount of unique weapons, armour and spells give you plenty opportunities to experiment with them and pick the one you like the most.I wouldn't say that Dark Souls is a hard game. It just doesn't hold your hand like most games do today and I think it is a nice nod to the unforgiving NES/SNES era. The difficulty of this game lies in the skill of the player. Also to get the best experience out of this game. Play this game with no guide or anything whatsoever.Now you may ask yourself, does this games have flaws? Yes, it does. The PC version has a large amount of framedrops (You will especially notice this if you have played the console version too), online matchmaking could be done better and a controller is almost required to play this game smoothly.But do these flaws stop me from enjoying this game? HELL NO! I say go get this game if you want a deep action RPG/dungeon crawler that will entertain you for hours.Praise The Sun, Sunbros!!  \o/

er 24, 2013
												Before anyone jumps down my throat, let me say this.  The difficulty of the game was NOT the reason for the thumbs down.  yes it is hard and it is really damn annoying at times, but it is extremely rewarding to finally make it through whatever boss or section of a map that you are playing.   The reason that I give it a thumbs down is largely because of how bad of a port the game was.   The graphics could have been enhanced more but they were good enough to get the job done, so that's a very very minor reason.   The issue with the port was the learning curve on what keys from the Xbox controller were corresponded to the keys on the computer.   I tried so hard to figure it out and got most of the things down but it was so frustrating.   But the worse part, was the mouse.  I used mods to fix it but it kept turning at 90deg turns and made it annoying to stay still.   And then finally, the "focus on enemy" feature, whatever it was called, was so bad because even when you would focus on one enemy, your mouse would grab another one and thus leave you wide open and in this game, that can cost you dearly. If they only cared enough to have changed the controls (especially the on screen buttons -.- then it would have been better to play, but they didn't.   I think this is better to just play on the console, rather than the PC.TL;DR  The game itself, is great, although tough, but the PC version of is a really bad port  UNLESS you use controller, which makes it much much easier to play.   As for KB&M users, use the mods made by players, or just get a controller.

content:
2016
												As the "chosen undead" you embark, spurred by a prophecy, on a pilgrimage that'll see you traverse the whole world of Lordran and ultimately decide its fate: it'll be a long, arduous journey that'll test the player character- and you as the player- several times.I agree with the notion that Dark Souls can be considered a flawed gem: it won't be for everyone, there's some questionable design decisions and it feels a bit clunky at times but when everything clicks the game is very fun and extremely rewarding.PROS:-when modded it looks quite nice considering its age-great soundtrack and sound design-a sprawling, interesting world to explore with some truly nice vistas-great combat system rewards skill, strategy and patience-the difficulty might be frustrating at times, but gives a great sense of progression as you slowly become able to tackle stronger foes and is immensely rewarding once you beat a difficult area or boss-bosses and minibosses are, for the most part, tense and engaging affairs: most bosses are also quite menacing due to their size and/ or art style-tons of different weapons, armours and spells to suit basically any playstyle-the multiplayer aspects are interesting, it's fun to see player ghosts going around their business and die: invasions can be a bit annoying at times but there's no denying they're fun and keep you on edge-very long, expect around 40/ 50 hours, plus you get DLC and New Game Plus modesNEUTRAL:-story is a tad muddy overall and its easy to get confused if you don't examine objects or talk to missable NPC (some of which can be missed)-inventory/ stats screens work but feel cumbersomeCONS:-blurry, muddy graphics when unmodded: also lacks most graphical options-problematic camera can really get in the way and lead to unfair deaths-some drawn-out sequences with no bonfires can get aggravating-if you die to a boss having to either clear the whole path to it(or try to run through mobs to quickly reach it again) simply gets dull -the lack of handholding and tutorials, apart from very basic ones, can leave new players stumped on what to do, how to spend their points and what build to aim for


Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition 
A Screenshot of Dark Souls: Prepare to Die Edition
By: stranger1982




Dark Souls will be intimidating for most when you start, heck it took me a few tries to just get to grips with combat against basic enemies: and the first bosses were messy affairs where I just ran around trying to roll/ parry just to be cut down in two hits. But persevering in the face of hardships yields results soon enough nad going back to a boss the next day only to beat it on the first try gives an huge sense of accomplishment. And that's really the whole game in a nutshell, bashing your face against difficult zones, strong enemies and huge bosses to eventually come out victorious once you get the hang of it.The difficulty that made the series famous sadly stems, in part, from the camera: it works decently most of the time but while fighting huge bosses/ mobs or traversing cramped spaces it can act up badly: and when it does you might not see an hit coming or simply become disoriented and die with little to no way to react. A few encounters are also designed in a purposedly cheap way...have to traverse a thin strip of stone over an huge chasm? We'll add ranged mobs just to ensure you might die a cheap death. These encounters feel outright annoying rather than challenging...same goes for having to walk over invisible platforms or fighting in almost pitch darkness, I did it and eventually made it but I felt relief rather than accomplishment in doing so.But even with all its flaws the game is a memorable experience, for me it was about going against overwhelming odds and persevering even in the face of multiple defeats: to try until you succeed, to know that there's always a way to come out on top, eventually. And it was also a story about sacrifice both in its plot and the actual game mechanics.Is this a game for you? Maybe, maybe not...it's not as difficult as certain people make it out to be (and if you're really frustrated or scared to tackle it, just read a guide to have a slightly easier experience) but it surely demands quite a bit of skill and lots of concentration to go through. And even if you can't beat it I feel even just a few hours with the game could be worth it even just for the cathartic experience it's able to provide.

												Unmatched Difficulty!/ Navigate a labyrinth of FAQs and forums as you take on the ultimate test of patience in trying to get your game to launch./ Engage in tireless trial and error as you attempt to smooth out your framerate and improve graphics and performance with 3rd-party mods./ Measure the true extent of your PC elitism upon realizing just how trashy the keyboard & mouse controls are.Hardcore Role-playing/Life Simulation!/ Select a class, meticulously customize your appearance, then play through the game unsatisfied with the final results. In fact, spend 95% of the game looking like your own corpse. Be reminded constantly of your own mortality and question the long-term merits of your purchase decision as you gaze into the lifeless eyes of your broken, decrepit avatar./ Sit at bonfires, refill flasks, wander off, pick fights, lose, black out, reawaken at bonfires... Lordran will help you prepare for your own future with this poorly-disguised alcoholism metaphor./ Shuffle forward like a real-life Mondoshawan as you put on increasingly heavy pieces of armor while believing the added pseudo-protection is actually worth it. Each another burden. Each a regret./ Continously fight the urge to access the wiki for information that will save you from dozens of wasted hours and disastrous mistakes. Go ahead. Go ahead and play God, you weak coward./ Stave off those suicidal thoughts by piecing together the lore and making up your own story as you're stuck fighting in the same area, against the same enemies, for entire sessions or even days. Let that imaginary world drift into reality so it can gradually take over for good.Oh and there's PvP!Break the monotony of dying against game stuff by taking on REAL people in this carefully-crafted fishing simulator minigame! There's so much to look forward to in enthusiast- and pro-level PvP!! Here's a sneak peak:- Backstabs- Strafe Backstabs- Lock-on Sprint Backstabs- Lock-off Sprint Backstabs- Roll Backstabs- Reverse-roll Backstabs- Delayed Lock-off Roll Backstabs- Roll-escape Punish Backstabs- Stagger to Sprint Backstabs- Chain Backstabs- Dual Backstabs- Poise-tank Backstabs- Toggle-escape Backstabs- Counter Backstabs- Backstab-escape Backstabs- Counter Backstab-escape Backstabs- Reverse Wakeup Chainstab Defense BackstabsAnd God knows what else! There's still so much more to discover!Results!Story: N/A / 0Music & Sound: Demon's Was Slightly Better / 10Level Design: 10 or more Pre-patched Bounding Demons in the Lava / 10Gameplay: What is Collision Detection / 10PvE: 99 Resistance / 10PvP: ALT+F4 / 10Replay Value: NG+7 / 10Overall: Large Ember / 10
