content:
2, 2014
												I'm going to write a serious review because I'm sick of seeing the "11/10 there was a butt" nonsense.It's a good game but it has it's flaws. I'd recommend it and I rate it 8/10. If you are looking for a challenging RPG that doesn't require grinding or deep deep levels of thought towards stats. If you enjoy hard boss fights that act as an exam on the game mechanics and enemies that will put up a fight, then this game is for you.Good:+The difficulty is not only offers a sense of challenge but also a sense of fear that any enemy can kill you if you dismiss it. It is mostly fair with one or two instances where it just gets silly, but that rarely happens. The feeling inside when you see a new type of enemy is a strangly good sense of fear and dread, wondering if they'll just up and one shot you, or explode or eat you is a weirdly great feeling.+The atmosphere is pretty depressing and dark which fits perfectly for the game.+World design is very good, the world not only is well connected but it aesthetically seems well connected. There is a vast array of areas that are extremely different, yet feel perfectly connected to each other.+Majority of the boss fights are fair, but only some are extremely hard (IMO). If you don't mess around and be serious you can smash most bosses. When you defeat a boss that you are having trouble on it is one of the best feelings leaving you wanting to play more.+Combat is very well designed. It's simple and easy to understand and once you get into the zone you will love just going from A-B because of the fantastic combat.+The multitude of ways to play makes the game replayable and diverse. You are also not locked into one class, you can level up into any stats you want leaving it open for unique play.+Story is interesting but quite shallow, it just left me wanting more of a story and I guess that's a sign of a good story that wasn't fleshed out enough.+PVP can be fun but it's too heavily affected by lag making it unfun and obtrusive, but this could just be a personal problem with lag so I'm adding it as a plus.+The RPG elements are easy to follow and understand, making it easy for you to get the most out of your character.Bad:-Controls can be a bit clunky, making the roll and jump the same button is terrible design, especially when there is no move    assigned to L3/Left thumbstick.-The port and GFWL make it pretty annoying to use, but this can easily be ignored-As for story, it's interesting but it's pretty shallow. Dark souls fans will always make note of how the story must be found and searched for, this is true. If you look for story and lore you will find it, but, when you do look into it you hit a brick wall quickly. There is a very small amount of background information in the game. Through the game I was super interested in the story, wondering who is this guy and what's his story, and I'd be met with 2 sentences about him. Also, too much of this lore is speculation and it's extremely vague. It's good to leave some things up to interpretation, but god. Not this much.-Bad possibly even the worst fanbase. This fanbase enjoys talking down to every other RPG over the casual pastime they enjoy, they refute any claims of bad game design (major or minor), claiming that it would literally ruin the game and they are just generally mean spirited towards anyone who doesn't like the game or has a genuine criticism. It's best to just avoid them and their elitism.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 21, 2014
												On your hero's journey to become a better gamer, nay, an objectively superior person, Dark Souls is your personal '80s training montage. It needs no tacked-on Achievements system, because every bit of meaningful progress you make is an achievement in itself. It needs no difficulty levels, because, like any rewarding video game, it starts on Very Hard, progresses to Insane (or, in Touhou parlance, "For Weird People",) and then smooths out to Hard mode once you've gotten the hang of it, which comes with the satisfying moment in which you realize you're ready for whatever comes ahead.You either outsmart the game, or you take a break and come back swinging after you have one of the many eureka moments you'll experience. You'll initially have a hard time figuring out how to be a smart-♥♥♥♥♥ ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and beat the baddies of Lordran at their own game, but in doing so, you will unleash the inner fighting spirit you had all along. Dark Souls is not just an inventive and engrossing game that makes a strong case for the evolution of games into an art form. It's not just a brilliant marriage of East and West game design values. It's also a teaching tool. Dark Souls will teach you to be cautious and aware of your environment, and the consequences of failure (namely through the Humanity system and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ basilisk curses.) Dark Souls encourages cooperation and compassion for your fellow players. You can be a ♥♥♥♥ and leave false post-its for other players, and/or gank them mercilessly to rob them of Humanity, but you really get a "we're all in this together" kind of feeling with the way the game rewards cooperation, assistance, and hunting down merciless invaders. It plays great, makes you feel like a badass, contains Berserk references, and is a brilliant example of environmental storytelling. And damn, those environments. What a gorgeous view.If you don't give Dark Souls a fighting chance (at least 10 hours of tryhard playtime,) you're an overgrown, stinky, pouting, grimacing, liliputian, whiny, poopy, little velcro-sneaker-wearing tyke. If you've given it a fair shot and don't like it yet, don't worry. You've proven you have the Guts to rise to the challenge. When you're ready. But harden your heart. You will get there, but it won't be easy. Prepare to die.A+

												Prepare to die over and over again. Prepare to lose all your progress, and sometimes your will. But also prepare for a journey through a scarred and forgotten land, of figures from a past guiding you forward on what seems to be your destiny. content:
er 24, 2013
												Renowned for being difficult and for good reason.  This game will test your patience as it throws you into a dark, dying world with little explanation and almost no equipment.  You will die.  You will die a lot.  But out of all the death comes understanding of the game.  And with understanding comes satisfaction.  Eventually the bosses will start to drop.  And someday you may understand what all the numbers in the menu mean.  Don't feel bad looking up guides to help you if you're super confused.  Better than quitting I say.  But don't let it do the work for you.  And don't spoil anything!  Discovery is the name of the game!This game has an excellent setting and even better enemy design.Praise the sun!P.S. Subpar port to PC.  There are several mods out there to help make the game run better.  Please PM me if you need help.  Absolutely worth it.

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 3, 2014
												Preaching to the choir a bit, but man, this game is pretty great.I'm going to save time and just give the cliff notes since I think everything has pretty much already been said otherwise.+ Lots of content. So many puzzles, weapons, spells, monster types, upgrade paths, shortcuts and secrets, everything! The game is ♥♥♥♥ing /packed/.+ Lots of variety. So many interesting locales. I'm almost wondering what they'll do for the sequel to spice it up since so many ideas have already been used. Maybe a blizzard area or a desert.+ It feels like a fantasy come to life. Interesting lore, fitting dialogue and voice acting. It's all so well realized.+ A very small number of reskins. Game feels fresh from start to finish.+ Rewarding. The boss fights are each like a puzzle which often trouble you the first go around but even simply give 1 retry and you can feel how you've improved. - Some things are a bit obtuse. Like, it's not clear why one would want to stock humanity points without looking it up. It feels safer to just keep the humanity items pocketed.- Wish there was better item management. You get a lot of items. For instance, I think identical weapons and armors should stack if you have multiples. Looking forward to Dark Souls 2!

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
ry 9, 2016
												Dark Souls.Spiritual successor to the Playstation 3 exclusive Demon Souls, with a well deserved reputation for being a brutal game. Dark souls is often touted as being "NES hard" compared to the hand-holding games of the modern generation, by the way the game implements hard but fair gameplay. The 3rd person fantasy RPG features a plethora of weapons to cater to a varity of different playstyles and a large world to explore.The game opens with a cinematic that gives the player a history of the first flame and souls, but the rest is left to the player to interpret and discover.Throughout the inter-connected world of Lordran you will find bonfires that restore your healing items (Estus Flasks) whenever you rest at them. The implementation of limited heals creates this 'risk vs reward' aspect to adventuring, where if you run out of your charges, you can either press on towards a new bonfire, or return to the old one to give it another go. The Bosses in Dark Souls are brilliantly crafted and offer both test of the players combat knowledge, figuring out the attack patterns, timing your attacks and healing, as well as the crawl back to the boss from bonfires testing your knowledge of the level.One minor gripe with Dark souls, is that lag can heavily effect gameplay in certain areas causing annoying deaths and damage. This happens rather rarely, as to not majorly affect the games otherwise good controls.All in all, Dark souls is an amazing game that is tough but fair giving a rich fantasy RPG experience to anyone who picks it up.Praise the sun!

number of helpful: 8 of 8 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 15, 2016
												For those whom haven't ever played a souls game before, then please read this. For those that have, and haven't played Dark Souls PTDE, then it's imperative you read this.Firstly, for those that don't know, Dark Souls is the first in a trilogy of games that boasts ever growing popularity as they are released, and is the best introduction into Souls games you will receive - gritty, bitter, soul crushing disappointment... followed by frustration, determination, perseverance and eventually insatiable lust. Yes, this is not a nice game, but it has the potential to be the best.Now, whilst you may have heard of the spiritual predecessor, Demon's Souls, and spiritual successor, Bloodborne; know that while they share similar mechanics, these game are not part of the Dark Souls trilogy, and shouldn't wholly determine whether you'll think you'll like this game - which they haven't otherwise you wouldn't be reading a review to make up your mind...START HERE IF YOU ONLY CARE FOR THE WORTHWHILE STUFF ::I'll start out by saying, this game isn't for the feint of heart. If you don't like difficulty, or you're not patient, or you think Skyrim can be hard... this isn't for you. I can tell you, I've played that crap with survival mods on legendary difficulty and all it does is bore me. Dark Souls brings difficulty and mixes it with ingenuity to create a whole new kind of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ tearing experience for the new player. But, it is a game that can be mastered, and within no time it shall be the player tearing ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s... of newbs... using twink builds - because we're all sadists at heart.Since we're on that topic, let's talk about combat. Dark Souls has one of the best, and most advanced combat systems of any RPG out there - easily combating that of Dragon's Dogma and other such games. FromSoftware has placed heavy focus on a mixture of tactical and reactive combat. One can win a fight using reflexes alone, but the game punishes you for not planning ahead. The player whom prepares properly, and learns their enemy, will find themselves breezing through most areas and bosses in no time.Stamina management is a key feature in Dark Souls. Stamina, shown as a green bar on the top left corner of one's HUD, determines the players ability to dodge, attack, block, parry, sprint, jump and at times can even affect the speed and damage of one's attacks. It is infinite, in that it recharges over time, but poor management can lead to a temporary loss of stamina, leaving the player wide open, and 90% of the time will result in death, or something close to it. Always be wary of your stamina.That aside, the combat system in Dark Souls is very complex. From 'sweet spot' attacks, which alter damage dealt depending on which part of your weapon strikes the enemy; to differing types of critical attacks, and the various damage types the game has on offer. One of the 'unseen' but easily recognised features of the game are enemies' weaknesses and resistances. While certain enemies will be weak to thrusting or slashing damage, they may be resistant to striking attacks... and vice versa. This same rule applies to the elemental types available in the game :- Magic- Fire- Lightning- Physical (which splits into Strike, Slash and Thrust)And on top of that are status effects :- Bleed - Poison- ToxinThis complex and diverse combat system allows almost infinite variety to every combat situation. Of course, certain things will work better against certain enemies, bosses, or even are better suited to the area (for example, using a smaller thrusting sword in a confined space yields better results than accidentally hitting the wall with your two-handed skyscraper)'I don't want to pour out a wiki full of content on a mere review, so I won't go too into detail about everything that I have mentioned and chosen to omit.Now, aside from basic combat, Dark Souls PTDE boasts some of the best boss fights in any game to date. This that have played other souls games can be prepared for on par and better boss fights than many of the best fights encountered in the Souls games, and Dark Souls 1 is home to the most renowned and notorious boss fight in the whole series (and one of the biggest souls memes) - so that should persuade you a bit.For those that haven't played a souls game... well, prepare to die. It's in the title. Many of the bosses in this game will kill you. Many times over. It is the player's responsibility to learn the boss - their move set, their weaknesses and strengths, and to learn to be patient with it. Greed, impatience and thoughtlessness are the biggest enemies of the Dark Souls player. As I said, if you aren't patient, then it isn't for you.Saying that, I do not wish. To imply, at all, that any boss in this game is boring and just a grind to do. Quite the opposite. Every boss, to me, in their own unique way is a fight to behold. Each will get your heart racing, as you battle epically against bosses a varying size and shape, from humanoids the size of you, to beasts the size of buildings, all accompanied by an astounding soundtrack - it will not disappoint... well, maybe one boss fight will, but we don't talk about that one.Though it was the first thing I spoke about, Combat is not the most important thing about Dark Souls (well it might be to some), but to me, the defining aspect of this game is the design. Set in a dark, fantastical, medieval setting - Dark Souls sets the player in one of the most flawlessly designed worlds to be seen in an RPG. The interconnected world, which intertwines on itself, with twists and turns at every corner leading to new and exciting areas as often as the well needed relief of realising it was a shortcut back to your last bonfire (effective checkpoint), will leave most in awe of just how flawlessly created this masterpiece is.The world itself is fully connected, with each area having a realistic and very visible geographical relation to one another. Most often, that place you see in the distance is somewhere you will travel later; and there's a peculiar sense of satisfaction in seeing the place you earlier surpassed off in the distance, and realising how far you've come since.Disregarding that, the area design (each area is interconnected, but have their own names and environments) is absolutely top-notch. With various paths in each area, and an abundance of verticality almost everywhere you travel, the player will often find themselves stumbling upon surprises of both the good and bad variety... good usually comes after defeating the bad surprise though. Sorry. No reward without sacrifice. Alongside this, Dark Souls puts heavy focus on both the sense of relief and sense of accomplishment, and it's area design is something that does this very successful. Bonfires, a place where one may rest and replenish Estus, level up, and later use to fast travel (plus more), are scattered about the world - though scarcely. Areas focus on these bonfires, using shortcuts to provide the much needed relief to the player after their gruelling trek through an area. Some, however, are well hidden, so ensure you always fully explore every nook and cranny... but don't let your guard down. Dark Souls rewards exploration, but it also has its fair share of methods to stop you getting all its loot for free - watch your back, and shield up when rounding corners.Now, with both combat and design vaguely covered, the next subject is narrative. Often the biggest complaint about Dark Souls is its lack of a compelling story, and lore. Well, to those that believe such lies, I slap you with a dirty dishcloth and tell you to roll up hill donning the Catarina Armour until you are dizzy enough to warrant thinking such things, at which point I will still say you are a fool. Dark Souls has an immensely complex, emotional and amazing storyline. I freaking ran out of space, so you'll just have to believe me. \[+]/

												My friends it is often been said that i like Dark souls, my friends i like Dark souls... NO i LOVE DARK SOULS I love invasions,I love hunters,i love gankers,gravelords,darkwraiths, sunbros, boss battles with big demons,dragons,hydras,spiders,Smough,Ornstein i love every possible battle that can occur in my world.I love blasting invaders into ash with Wrath of gods that echo during battle :)My hearth leaps into joy whenever an invader gets pawned by well placed Dark Beads :DAnd there's nothing like a big Daddy that uses his Zwei to obliterate his victims:)And the felling that comes when a Moonlight user runs scared from you when you cast Great Magical Barrier only to be cut down by your chaos blade is such a exquisite feeling:D---It moves my hearth when a new Hollow dies over and over only preparing to die more:DThe sight of Chuggers getting bs punished is a irresistible pleasure :)And theres nothing  better then the sound of hatemail filling your inbox from butthurt players :DWhen a band of gankers try to defeaT me without their estus only to be crushed  by my claymore im in ecstasy :DDDI love it when all of my gathered souls and humanity  are lost  after  falling down in sen's fortressIt's so sad killing quelags sister simply because you pressed the wrong button yet you only wanted to give her more humanity ;(I love being squashed by Smough and Ornstein's bottom'sThe humiliation as you keep lossing to that one guy who keeps gesturing down on you .GENTELMEN ALL I ASK OF YOU IS FOR YOU TO GET THIS GAME!Gentelmen I ask you as fellow hollows  do you wish for more bloddy  battles as I do ?Battles that are built from hatters,ragequits and buthhurts ?DO you ask for battles that will make your heart pump a hundred  times faster even after the bloodstains of your opponents are gone?!We are but couple of battalions since Dark souls 2 came to be, however I believe each of our Dark souls hollows is equal to a thousand of their sickly soft players !

content:
11, 2014
												Reminiscent of old-school gaming, Dark Souls is brutally unforgiving. It's fair though and 99% of your, frustratingly frequent, deaths will be due to your mistakes. When you clear one of the diverse and sometimes breath-takingly beautiful sections, another of the crazy and imaginative boss fights or find a secret area or piece of lore (of which the game hints at and can be delved into quite deeply if you so wish) you feel an immense sense of satisfaction and achievement. Interesting and exciting multiplayer opportunities (shame about Windows Live though), done in quite a unique way is thrown in too.Most modern gaming has automatic transition. Dark Souls is fully manual and you'll stall many times. But once you can smoothly drive you will feel like you're king of gaming.BUY THIS GAME.

0, 2016
												You're going to hate it for about an hour, then you will realize the following:The game is punishing, but rewarding.  You die a lot, but you lose nothing.  Every death is meant to be a learning experience.  After you get over this you can see that the combat is beautifully in depth.  The game world is amazing and seemlessly connected.  The atomsphere is amazing.  Everything about the game after getting your ♥♥♥ handed to you a few times is amazing and created beautifully.  Yes its hard, but the difficulty is rewarding, and everything you do in game feels satisfying.  Some tips:1.  Use a controller.  Sorry KB+M purists its just better.2.  Until you get good at abusing invuln frames on rolling use your shield liberally.  A good shield can block all but magic damage.3.  Weapon Upgrade >  Character levels.  A halbred + 5 will get so much done whereas 5 more levels are marginal at best.

content:
ry 18, 2015
												\ |T| /Metroidvania-like exploration. Easy-to-learn, hard-to-master, not-too-bad-to-get-fairly-okay-at combat. A world with a complex history and obfuscated fate, and characters with more depth than they let on.First, the good.Dark Souls is known to be "hard" or sometimes even "unfair". I strongly disagree with the use of those terms. Challenging, yes, certainly.A lot of modern games featurea hell of a lot of hand-holding. Lengthy tutorials, excessive hints, storytelling like you're listening to teacher read from a book.Dark Souls has none of these things.Dark Souls respects its players enough to let them figure out how the world works on their own.People who are used to the handholding may find themselves utterly lost in the world of Lordran - this is a perfect opportunity to get back into the old-school 'explore places and try things' mindset.The key to getting through Dark Souls alone is a matter of keeping to a mindful approach. Keep an eye out for items. Always be prepared for combat. Listen carefully to what the NPCs have to say; they drop subtle hints about where you can or need to go, what the backstory is about, and it is important to note that they do NOT repeat the more important things they say.Don't worry though - missing dialogue won't stop you from advancing. Not at all. The dialogue is merely there to aid your understanding of your purpose and the world you are in. None of the lore is forced upon you, save for the single opening cutscene which explains little but hints at a lot. In fact, the lore is carefully hidden away, waiting to be discovered and puzzled out by anyone who would seek it.Gameplay-wise, it feels clunky to start with, as all the unfamiliar options and weapons are open to you to be found, and/or left strewn across the world without ceremony. Soon enough, though, the controls will feel nothing short of intuitive, and this *includes* the option of playing with keyboard only (look up the keyboard controls in a guide and give them a go. Dark Souls does not *require* a controller, as such).Dark Souls respects your ability to learn how to deal with the obstacles it presents, and that applies to every detail. The greater part of advancing in Dark Souls is less about leveling up and more about your own personal skill, which you'll find will naturally develop as you play the game. When you beat a boss, or even any minor foe, you'll feel the satisfaction of knowing it was your own skill that overcame it. The fact that you happen to be level 258 or so is merely a small aid, and adds a side dish of a sense of personal progress.It is in fact entirely possible to beat the game whilst being level 1.Don't try that for your first run.On the whole, the positive aspects of Dark Souls outshine what I have previously called the pinnacle of my gaming experience by a long shot. If you adore adventure, exploration, skill-based combat, atmospheric environments, deep story, and RPG elements, or any combination of at least two of those, this game is for you.Next, the bad.Uh.Well, the tutorial's just a little bit cruel to less experienced gamers. Not too much so, though. Again, learn from things and you'll be fine.Sometimes it is possible to get lost or stuck somewhere, if you missed a door or a key for example, and you may be forced to bring in either the help of spoiler-riddled guides, or a trusted friend. Though Jolly Cooperation is in no way a bad thing; you might even find it enhances the atmosphere in some cases.The voice acting is merely passable. Barely even that, really. Dark Souls features a good lot of talented voice actors, but what may have been poor direction has left a lot of their lines sounding a bit.. theatrical. Not that it matters so much; there's all too many things to make up for that in the feel of the game itself.Also, some storylines pertaining to some of the characters nearly brought me to tears. That was unexpected. But a good sign of immersion!On the whole, Dark Souls definitely has some rough edges. But then I've never found a true work of art that didn't.Come for the challenge, stay for the delightful immersion into the strange, unusual world, and in thine exodus from the Undead Asylum, thou better damn well Praise the Sun.

content:
er 30, 2013
												Well, the title says a lot. You will die: a lot. However, you will savor every death as you struggle to improve your own abilities and survive in the oppressive world that From Software has created. The greatest achievement of Dark Souls, to me, is that it treats you like an adult. It does not hold you hand, it does not force endless tutorials or make you follow some generic NPCs as you mow down waves of unnamed brown dudes. No, Dark Souls let you jump into the action rather quickly and teaches you everything you need to know from the getgo in a very unobtrusive manner. Combat is a struggle as you try to read the enemies' attack patterns and react accordingly with your own moves. If you play it like a traditional hack and slash, you will die and go nowhere. Therefore, everything becomes a game of balancing aggression and defense as you learn when to engage, how to engage, when to evade, and when to block. If this sounds complex, that's because it is. Dark Souls will suck up numerous hours of your time with all of its nuances and secrets. But the one glaring blemish on an otherwise fantastic experience is the PC port. To be blunt, it's just not very good. It's a very barebones port that utilizes very little of the aspects that we love about PC gaming. However, DSFix largely ameliorates many of these issues, allowing you to play the game at a higher resolution and higher framerate, making it the definitive version of the game. Games For Windows Live, unfortunately, exists in this game and is a huge pain in the ♥♥♥. You'll be disconnected from LIVE in the middle of an epic boss fight (it happened to me on the Bell Gargoyles the first time around) and kicked back to the title screen or have save data deleted because GFWL uses a primitive patching system that serves as a massive inconvenience. The keyboard controls, while functional (especially with community fixes) are far from optimal. You'll definitely want a controller for this game. Finally, the game can chug at times even on a high end rig, so don't expect a perfectly smooth experience.However, despite all of that, Dark Souls is a fantastic game. In fact, I'd say it's one of the best games I've played in a very long while. The sense of accomplishment you feel as you claw your way through its brutal world or fend off hostile monsters that can easily kill you is practically uncontested. Most importantly, Dark Souls respects YOU as a player and does not baby you or insult your intelligence. It's a truly refreshing experience and one that most gamers should pick up, provided they're willing to overlook a lackluster port.

												I honestly wanted to like this game. At first it seems like a refreshingly tough action-RPG. However, the elements that make this game so hard aren't great enemy AI and challenging gameplay, but repetative and frustraiting mechanics that seem like they're creating just to make this game so difficult. There's a reason modern games have adopted frequent checkpoints - restarting areas again and again is more  annyoing than fun. Losing what you'd spent the last fourty minutes farming because one enemy managed to pull off a suprise combo just makes me wondering why I'm devoting free time towards something that feels like work. Watch some of the boss battle guides on youtube - most of them direct you to use some kind of exploit to win instead of describing a strategy to use to actually beat the boss fairlly. That's because most of the fights consist of blocking/countering again and again...that's it.

content:
r 26, 2015
												Dark Souls; the game with an infamous reputation.When it first released, I was skeptical as to whether I wanted to buy a game that had a reputation for being harder than trying to break into Fort Knox. So, as a result, I avoided buying it. However, in the summer of this year (2015), I decided, why the hell not?  During the Summer Sale I bought it for roughly £7. (I forgot the specific price.) I can safely say now, after clocking up almost 300 hours on Dark Souls, and counting, that the purchase was absolutely worth it. So, let's get some context shall we? (There's a lot of context, so be warned!)[Also! Dark Souls likes to follow the story-telling method of not telling you the story; if you want to know the lore, you've got to go research it!]~Set in a pseudo-medieval fantasy world, the game explains that long before the present time, the world was grey, ultimately rocky and dusty and covered by huge 'Arch Trees'. This world was ruled over by the 'Everlasting Dragons' ; aptly named because they were immortal. At this time, there was no light or dark; no life or death in the world, only the Everlasting Dragons.~At some point in this world, Fire was born (The game doesn't really explain how, so run with it) and from this flame was born four 'Lord Souls' (Souls in the game, act as a sort of power source for magic and the like, as opposed to being a representation of one's personality.) Three of these souls were found by the 'Lords', a race of humanoid creatures that would later become the 'Gods' of the world, while the fourth was found by the 'Furtive Pygmy', who is widely believed to have been the ancestor of Mankind/The first Human. (I'm not going to explain this story arc; go look it up if you wish to know more.) ~The Lords rebelled against the Everlasting Dragons, and using their one weakness (lightning-based magic), peeled apart the stone scales that gave the Dragons their immortality. (Without their scales, the Everlasting Dragons are not immortal) The Lord's succeeded, The Dragons were wiped out (supposedly) and this ushers in an 'Age of Fire'; where light and dark, life and death are brought into the world.~Now, in between then, and the game start, there's a lot of lore that I won't go into (Again, go research the lore; It's really worth it), but it's safe to say that the Age of Fire began to dwindle and the power of the 'Gods' began to crumble.~Fast forward to the present, the world is but a shadow of its former self; with both Kingdoms of the Lords and Human Kingdoms lying in complete desolation. This is because of the 'Curse of Undeath', a condition that replaces death with a form of immortality. However, the reason why it's called a curse is because those who are Undead with no purpose and no motivation/will to live will 'go Hollow', wherein they lose their minds and become reduced to mere husks. These husks are then plagued to wander the world forever; as nothing but shadows of humanity. They are hostile: attacking whoever gets close to them.~This, is where you come in. You are a cursed undead waiting to go hollow in an asylum. However, you are freed from your cell to fulfill an ancient prophecy to 'Re-kindle the Age of Fire' (Again, go look it up). And from there on, your quest begins.(Big nutshell I know, but this game has metric shed-tonnes of lore!) So! With that explained, what's the actual game like?~Well, the game does have a reputation for being very difficult, and whereas I didn't really have too much trouble with the game myself, I understand that it can be quite hard to get used to. The game could be said to be a hack 'n' slasher, but also an action-adventure game with RPG elements. At the start of the game, you pick a class to play, (classes include pyromancers, knights, sorcerers etc) and you then play through the game, levelling up and gaining new items to fit that class. The classes can be blended, so don't think that if you pick knight, you're stuck to using melee for the rest of the game; you could do a knight-sorcerer blend, or a knight-pyromancer etc etc etc. ~The combat (which is basically the core gameplay mechanic of Dark Souls), is very well polished and rounded. It's dangerous enough to maintain a high level of challenge, but balanced enough to be (relatively!) fair; if you die, there's a 90% chance that is was YOU that screwed up, not the game. This balance means that whenever you die, you don't become exasperated, you simply grit your teeth and go at it again. (Not always, but you rarely get to the instance where you might ragequit from the game) In addition, the game carefully avoids being artificially difficult (enemies with ridiculous health bars or stupid amounts of DPS etc), and is instead naturally difficult; with the difficult relying on how well you play the game, not how high-level you are. (It is entirely possible to complete the game without levelling up at all!) ~The game also includes a unique game-mechanic called the 'Humanity system'. I shan't go into the lore, but basically, humanity can be picked up from monster drops as an item, and absorbed from fallen enemies as 'liquid humanity' (Humanity picked up as items can be used to increase the amount of liquid humanity you possess). This 'liquid humanity' is used to kindle bonfires (basically more health kits at checkpoints), and also to reverse the hollowing process. When you die in Dark Souls, you lose your liquid humanity, and also your 'Souls' (ingame currency for BOTH purchases and levelling). You can go to recover them from the last safe place you stood before you died, but if you die on the way there, they are gone forever. ~This is due to the constantly moving world of Dark Souls, and that you can't simply revert a save in Dark Souls; a choice made is a choice made, it cannot be reversed or altered for the rest of the playthrough. (Again, another way the game is naturally challenging.) ~You can also transition from two separate player states within the game; Human and Hollow. When hollow, you cannot interact with other players of the game, and you cannot summon NPCs to help you with certain boss fights. When Human, you can summon both NPCs and other players into your world for co-op play, but you also run the risk of being invaded by hostile players who seek a duel to the death. Therefore, it is recommended that you traverse most of the world as a hollow, only converting back to human when you need help with a boss or an area.All of these factors combine to make the challenging, yet highly entertaining, odyssey that is Dark Souls.ALL IN ALL, DARK SOULS IS A FANTASTIC GAME.I sincerely enjoyed the time I spent playing this game, and I intend to play it for many, many more hours to come. It's tough, engaging, and ultimately, barrels filled with puppies and kittens of fun. This game is definitely worth you buying it!

content:
, 2014
												Prepare To Die is a good addition to this game's name. You will die. Lots of times. There is no getting around it. However, the first death is also the first step.Dark Souls is a 3rd Person RPG, set in a fantasy world with very dark themes. You've probably heard about this game from a friend or some person on the internet, and one of the things you've probably heard is the challenge involved. Yes, this game is incredibly hard. No, it is not unfair in any way, and yes, you can do it.There's a fairly high barrier to entry for the game, and even then the difficulty is higher than your normal game. However, Dark Souls is not unfair or just a bunch of cheap tactics. The kind of difficulty it presents is respectful. It isn't something like CoD's Veteran difficulty, where they just make the AI react as soon as you enter the room and one shot kills, making many certain spots impassable. Instead, they use creative enemy placement and tight controls to give you the feeling that even though you died this time, you can overcome it the next time. It has a great feelnig of trial and learning by error.This is why the death mechanics are what they are, because when you die you lose all of your accumulated souls (kind of like EXP) and "humanity", but if you can go to where you died you have a shot at getting them back. But, die again and they all disappear forever. It gives a feeling that you learn from death, because when you enter that room where you died to get your souls back, you know the surprise that killed you, and can prevent it from happening again. It's a lot like the mantra "Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, shame on me".But good and difficult gameplay is not the only thing Dark Souls has to present. The game presents a world deeply rooted in lore, and you decide your level of involvement with the plot. Maybe you wonder how this person got here or how the situation got as dire as it is, and search through item descriptions and NPC chat to find the answer. Or just pass off the backstory of the horrible monstrosity in front of you and say "Who cares, the game has presented me with another trophy for my wall!". This method of story telling is so that the story does not intrude upon the game, as there are few cutscenes, and the few that there are are very short, and it helps give the game an interconnected, continuous feeling, and contributes to the dark themes of the game.In addition to these themes, the game radiates a fantastic atmosphere. The HUD is very non intrusive, only conveying what it needs, and the game continues even if you are in the pause menu changing your gear. Its a sense of continuous action, and that you cannot let your guard down. Graphics are very good, and the game only puts in what it needs. See a giant castle or cave in the distance? You're probably gonna go there at some point. It all gives a sense that you have a purpose and a mission, and that you have to keep moving, even with all the depression included in this world. The soundtrack is also very good, being there at the critical points of the game, such as boss fights. At a lot of points there are silence, but this contributes to the feeling that the game is very tense. In general, everything the game includes is only what is necessary, no extra bits for the sake of content.Even the multiplayer is there for the sake of the game. There are 3 main types of ways players can interact with each other. First, players can scrawl messages on the ground for others to see, perhaps warning them of an upcoming ambush or trap, or misguiding them due to malicious intent. You have to choose which messages to trust carefully if you want to live. The 2nd way is by summoning white phantoms. Players may leave summon signs on the ground and get help from other players, or even NPC's. They help the player throughout the level, and disappear once the area boss is defeated, but not without reward. It fosters good intent among people. Then, the 3rd way is by invasion of a world for PvP. Players may use specific items in the game to "invade" another player, coming into their world as a dark spirit to kill them and steal their "humanity" and souls. The multiplayer is not a simple deathmatch added for the sake of multiplayer, its there to enhance and enrich the game experience.Overall, Dark Souls can be summed up as challenge through tight gameplay, creative enemies and terrain and unique multiplayer, with a great atmosphere provided by good graphics, soundtrack and a plot that you can uncover at your own leisure (though the low FPS cap for this doesn't help). All in all, an outstanding game that respects the capabilities of the player by providing difficulty not for difficulty's sake, but for the player's benefit. Prepare to die. But prepare for great emotional reward as well.

content:
er 8, 2013
												This is one of the best games of this generation. What makes it so? A formula very close to the one present in games called "Metroidvanias". In short, the idea is that we have a game world almost freely explorable. Almost, because some elements require certain things of the player, be it an item, skill or practical knowledge. The design tries to not implore the one right way, leaving an aspect of creativity for the players. This, in case of a Metroidvania game, Super Metroid, allowed to form a strong community focused on sequence breaking and optimizing playthroughs in the means of tool assisted speedruns. Dark Souls seem to acknowledge such efforts and provide players with tools to unite in cracking the game open. Bloodstains, messages, summoning and on the other hand, PvP, makes you feel being a part of an interesting and mysterious endeavour.While Dark Souls does not have as flexible game world as Super Metroid, it adds its own fresh element in form of eeriness. There is no holding hand so present in 99% of modern video games. Hints are obscure and subcutaneous, in form of item descriptions and vague stories told by NPCs. In fact, most of the plot-meat hides there. One would think this equals to weak lore or story, yet quite the opposite happens. Remember 8-bit games and how you wondered what this sprite really portaits, or imagined details beyond what was shown to you? Remember the feeling of reading your first books? This is what Dark Souls brings: the canvas for you to draw on with your imagination while the game provides brushes and inks.Dark Souls has one important gameplay aspect: you can be killed as easily by the boss as the weakest enemy. This effectively works as a kind of intimidation - you want to be cautios and situations can get tense. At the same time, your mistakes are almost always costly and the landscape also works against you. All of these create a tremendous immersion effect and often make you reconsider your approach, all the while instilling humility into you.What really makes the game fun at the core is the fighting system. The animations are detailed, attacks have the feel and power to them, different weapons have vastly different animation styles. Parry and backstab mechanics are plenty rewarding and never get old.RPG fans can find huge amounts of customization and variety of playthroughs, but what's important is that the game is fairly balanced in terms of equipment. A weaker gear can be just as much viable, because movement and attack style are equally important with damage dealt.Lastly, you have huge amounts of satisfaction coming from won boss fights and clearing areas, but that's only the resultant of coherent design which allows you to learn, improve and fight with your weaknesses.If you want to play a modern video game which does not insult your intelligence and does not constantly put a carrot on a stick in front of you, by any means, check it.

content:
26, 2012
												Dark Souls is a marvel of its time, a game that reminds us that we shouldn’t be satisfied with well-produced mediocrity and “good-for-what-it-is” games. It’s challenging, mature, deep, polished, and above all, a game that respects its players. There’s no hand-holding here, you’ll learn the ropes by playing, and the game will test you at every step, frequently killing you. The challenges are finely tuned, appearing almost impossible at first, but are in fact perfectly fair and doable, and a source of great satisfaction once beaten. The fantastic combat takes the center piece here, being easily the best you’ll find in any Action-RPG. It requires tactic, demands attention and rewards patience like no other; all while providing you a vast array of weapons and armors to equip, and diverse enemies to test them, through expertly designed levels. Another high point, the melancholic story is masterfully told through subtle details in the scenery, hints in the items descriptions and concise, well-written lines from a cast of memorable NPCs, never relying in long expositions or lazy “Lore Books” by wannabe-writers.From Software raised the bar with Dark Souls; it’s not the best game ever, but it’s one that excels in absolutely everything that it does.

content:
er 13, 2013
												This challenging fantasy action RPG throws you into a world where little can be taken at face value. The story is told in small conversations with NPCs and in item descriptions & placement. Incredible detail has been put into everything about this game which has a large community that regularly put out additional content (lore videos) that help expand a player's perception of characters. The combat is responsive and hinges of a huge variety of weapons, armour, and spells which really shines when you start playing online (and seeing all the crazy builds other people have come up with).There are some technical hiccups however, with the biggest being the GfWL DRM causing some issues with the innovative co-op/PVP aspect of the game. GfWL is also set to go down at some time in 2014, so hopefully the game will be patched to use Steam to handle the multiplayer in the future.In summary: this is a brilliant game, but a terrible port. If you can see past the technical issues, install the DSFix, and have a controlpad to hand, you may just fall deeply in love with this game.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ber 23, 2015
												Great game. It's not really the kind of game where you join up with a bunch of people and fight waves of monsters, it's more like you're one of the last people on the planet, everyone else is either undead or becoming undead, and every once in a while you can have the opportunity to join up with another player like you.The game is locked at 30fps, but you can unlock it with a mod. Supposedly it's a bit buggy at 60fps, but I've never bothered to try it. Dark souls is an RPG, you level up as you collect souls, you choose what stats to level etc. The contols are simple and within an hour or so you should have them down. This game shines in the customization department. There are tons of weapons and pieces of gear that can allow you to play whatever you feel like, even if you feel like playing some sort of green-skinned monster, you can do it. The game world is lots of fun to go through, because it's all interconnected. There are no loading screens as you walk from one place to another, the entire world is essentially a labyrinth, and it is quite satisfying to discover all the connecting points and shortcuts throughout.Personally I think what sets dark souls apart is the feeling of intimidation you get when you see a monster 10 times your size, and realize that you have to find a way to kill it before moving on. It's a challenge, based largely on trial and error combined with skill, it is not for those who want to be spoon fed an interactive story. As frustrating as dark souls can be, it matches it and sometimes exceeds it with the feeling of accomplishment.

content:
ry 23, 2014
												This game is the most satisfying game I have ever played to date. I highly recommend it to people who like games that will immerse you in the games world 100% and make you feel like your characters success is your success. When anything and everything can turn out to be an enemy or trap you will be kept on the edge of your seat for your entire play through. Throughout the course of that play through you will encounter next to imposable boss battles and relentless environments that will test your wits and sanity. However every time you conquer one of those ‘impossible’ boss battles the sensation is next to imposable to describe but the sound you’ll make may be something like this “gaaAAAFFFF-aahhhh-YES!!” as you either jump out of your chair throwing your hands and flailing your feet or slump back in your seat and let out a sigh of relief. Either way you will have felt like you’ve leaped over Mount Everest 300 thousand times over and high-fived the heavens. The environments in this game may seem like an impossible feat at times, and maybe a little unfair if you don’t watch what you’re doing or where you step, because that thought will always be in the back of your mind like it was mine when you only have 25% health and but a single estus flask left. “I have to fight a boss after this!?” But worry not future warrior for once you embark on this journey the one thing that will raise your spirits possibly more than conquering the bosses, avoiding booby-traps, exploring enormous landscapes and finding rare loot. “What could be better than all those things?” you may ask. I have but two words for you. The Bonfire. The bonfire is the light at the end of your monster filled tunnel, it is what keeps you going and what keeps you sane, it is your savior and your home, it brings relief and peace of mind in a chaotic world. This is a journey that in my book ranks above all others because it is a real ‘do it yourself’ kind of game that does not walk you through the game like a diaper baby, oh no. In this world you may enter as a naïve wanderer but you will leave a seasoned veteran who feels like they have the world in the palm of their well armored hands, that “this game wasn’t so hard, I bet I can do it again no problem” as you chuckle to yourself. Well Dark Souls will take you up on that, several times over in fact. Conquering this adventure once was by no means and easy feat but should you have the resolve and will for it, have another go at it, only this time lets amp it up and make every single thing two times stronger and seemingly a thousand times more deadly. Every time it gets harder but simultaneously more and more satisfying. Dark Souls will take you to the brink of death and then shotgun you to success if you have what it takes. If you think you do, than dive into the madness and delight. Just, press, start.

content:
ber 26, 2014
Oh, Dark Souls...This is one of those games that I have trouble expressing my opinion on it.I've played Demon's Souls previous to playing Dark Souls, so when I got this one I kind of knew what to expect from it... How wrong was I!I expected a great game, not an excellent one! This game is by far one of the best games I've ever played, hands down.Right, the review.Dark Souls: Prepare To Die Edition is a masterpiece.Everything about this game is beautiful, the levels, the enemies, the weapons, the combat, the magnificent multiplayer, the lore (if you care about it), and much more!So many secrets lie within the huge world of Dark Souls, you'll spend dozens of hours just to complete your first playthrough, not to mention that there is a new difficulty level each time you complete the game, to a cap of 7!You'll also, uhm... DIE A LOT! But that's only if you deserved it - if you're not good enough or are not approaching your enemies carefully, you will get punished for sure!You can create your own character, name it and change the looks of it. Then you get to choose a class and some starting gear.In this game you'll also meet NPC's, some of which have their own paths and objectives, and you can deal with those how you see fit. Did you just meet with some guy and he seemed friendly? Why not joining forces? Or maybe you met with the son of the devil, you'll probably want to keep your distance. Or, just kill them all. No boundaries, right?I won't go into much more of a detail, because the very first time I played this game I walked in completely blind and climbed my way up through some difficult situations, had to explore and learn how things worked by myself, and I loved every bit of it! So I won't spoil you the surprises.Basically, if you're into RPG's with real time combat, where the story revolves around you (not some character made up by the developers), then this game is a must! It's a very unique game (not counting the other Souls games) within its genre. But it has a VERY BIG PROBLEM called Games For Windows Live*. But if you have no issue with that, go ahead!*The game isn't supported by GFWL anymore, and it is working decently so far (23/12/2014), so I'd still recommend you to buy this game.Also, this game was meant to be played with a controller (since it's a PC port from consoles), so if you're having trouble using a PS3 controller, check out my tutorial about it on my profile.

content:
er 29, 2013
												The ultimate action RPG. This is for people who can enjoy trial and error and have the patience to learn from their mistakes. The game isn't "hard" like the hype says, but rather gives the player a fair challenge and punishes them for making mistakes. There is also an exploration element since the world is semi open world, by which I mean the map is a cobweb of pathways. The plot is very vague as well which adds to the mystery of the world. The gameplay is heavily based on learning attack animations of enemies and the weapons you use. There's also thematic online multiplayer. This is where you can have jolly co-operation or invasion where either you or someone else are going to be killed.Also here are my tips to newbies:* Use DSfix* Use a PS3 or Xbox360 controller to play* Only look up a guide if you get stuck, because looking at a guide from the start hinders your ability to learn the game* If you're going the melee route, keep in mind that the stat Endurance is very helpful* With armor, mobility is important but Poise is helpful as well* Go human once and awhile, you're missing out on the unique multiplayer experience if you don't!And for when you inevitably get stuck, remember this: Explore everything; if something doesn't work try something new! Experiment!

content:
14, 2014
												Dark Souls. The name alone sent shivers up my spine when a friend recommended it a month ago, notorious for it's sheer brutatlity and such little attempts to hold your hand or guide you along the way,I went in expecting to get my ♥♥♥ handed to me...i was correct xD Luckily i emerged victourious and haven't felt so majestic about a game in my life BAHAHA! I don't know what kept me going, but just that feeling of evolving from a scrawny, half naked, low level wanderer, desperately attempting to defend off simple hollows while wielding a striaght sword hilt...to an almighty force to be reckoned with wielding a Black Knight Greatsword battling Taurus Demons in the lava plauged wastes of Lost Izalith...was immense! This game also brings along a sense of strong entitlement upon completion, having beaten one of the most difficult games out in todays world, you can deffinitely call yourself a true gamer <3Please have a go at this game and don't give up, The start is a challenge then the rest of the journey is amazing fun and rewarding, with a few major highlights that left me sitting in pool of tears and banging my head agains the wall! E.g Blight Town those pesky little s**ts with the toxic darts! at first i was like wtf hit me and how did i get toxic...OMG IM LOSING SO MUCH HEALTH SO FAST!!!!!....then i saw the tiny specks they call "toxic darts"...Anor Londo, Silver Knight Archers and those f**king walk ways..haha, ORNSTEIN AND SMOUGH! oh my god never have i enjoyed such a hardship of a fight the best (and most straining) boss battle in the game in my opinion! (Basically just anor londo in general LOL!) Dukes archives sucked a bit with those damn channelers and archers :P Crystal Cave with those invisble walk ways and damn clams!!! Still think they are the hardest regular enemies xD Then the final fight of Gwyn Lord of Cinder! I went in not knowing wtf parrying even was LOL once i trained for hours how to parry and could make my way all the way to his fog door past 5 Black Knights without taking any damage and parrying the whole way, i could finnaly stand a chance!This game is like the Mona Lisa of art, everyone should play it. Bring on NG+- 10/10 GG Praise the Sun!

er 15, 2016
This ember burns down low... you hear the song ringing in your head. You grip your broken sword as you plunge it into the head of the Asylum Demon barring your way to the Firelink Shrine, the tutorial of this game a vicious boss fight.I would give it all... you realize you aresinging to yourself to maintain yoursanity.DARK SOULS PREPARE TO DIE EDITIONThe giant raven airdrops you into theruins of the game's first area, and thesense of senselessness, dread and pureatmosphere of the game beckons youwith the sight of the Bonfire, the way inwhich you respawn after death andenemies reset, your currency of soulsredrawing to zero.It was not always like this. And a game,a world the likes of DARK SOULS is notone for the faint of heart, the man withsomething to live for, the casul. Onceyou had a promising future, bright andlit after Ms. Novocaine left you and theGoddess of the Sun, Summer-Rain cameinto your life. But it has been six months since that May,since she was gone. The sickness hadravaged her, and videogames were heronly refuge from the pain eating away ather body. She sought refuge in the loveof the controller, the keyboard and mouse,and in you.You were in denial at her loss for six months,and at long last, in November, the month offate, is when you were shaken out of yourstupor and idleness. You having withdrawnfrom the world and your friends moved onor given up, graduated. In the end, it wasnot your friends who saved you then, butyour enemies."Coldheart." The terse voice states, like acommand from the Keepers, serpents ofDARK SOULS who have guided and chidedmankind.Killer's Conscience, leader of the Trinity ofHollywood, your enemies, leans against thedoor, looking at you while you explore thegame's worst and infamous area, the talland poisonous ramshackle swamp ofBlighttown. "Starboy. It has been months.""Yeah." You manage, entering a mountainmade of pure cobwebs, which itself morphsinto a church bordering on magma. Thedesign of DARK SOULS is varied, entwinedto a meticulous degree and populated bycreatures sparsely, giving you a viciouschallenge with their relentless A.I."I'm sorry." Killer's Conscience manages,as you fight the strangely attractivehalf-spider witch Queelag. You ring thesecond bell to gain access to the game'sprimary draw, the area of Anor Londo,a beautiful gothic expanse which is emptysave for the enemies which bay for yourblood.Killer's Conscience is livid, but impressedat your progress, marvelling at how farand how efficient you have become atkilling, at blazing through the horde ofmonstrosities keeping you from yourobjective, reigniting the heart of anepoch, the First Flame, to prevent theage of Darkness from consuming all."You're pretty good." Killer's Consciencesays after awhile, seemingly meditatingon your progress as a silent, almostnonexistent observer. "Thanks." yourreply comes without thought, as younow enter the antechamber with thetwo posterboys of pain, DragonslayerOrnstein and Executioner Smough!You grunt a response, as you finish offOrnstein. Smough absorbs his power,but then Killer's Conscience steps nextto you as you finish off Smough, andyou collect his loot and souls. You lookat him expectant, guessing he will tryto fight you as some next boss fromDARK SOULS itself like you both usedto, when Summer-Rain was alive."You haven't touched the DLC? Theone with the lost land of Oolacile andKnight Artorias?" You shake your headwithout a word, walking towards thedouble doors of Queen Gwynevere,whose chest is the stuff of legend."Haven't even fought Black DragonKalameet... I need to retrieve-"You are about to finish the sentencewhen Killer's Conscience presentswhat you seek in the game. Youblink in disbelief at what one ofyour enemies has presented you."The Lordvessel." You gasp."Yes." Killer's Conscience replies.You look back at him, your owncharacter static in DARK SOULSitself. Your eyes flash, and Killer'sConscience knows the look youhave... after all, he had it once as well."Is it true? Can it..." You begin, your voice cracking, images ofSummer-Rain inexplicably glazeover you and overlay with yourvision of Killer's Conscience andthe present. "Yes." He begins inresponse to you, gesturing as theempty Lordvessel, a teleportingartifact of power beckons beforeyour eyes. "It cannot bring ourSummer-Rain back... but not yet."You blink once more in utter disbelief."What...?!" Killer's Conscience leavesthe Lordvessel before you, and tells youto repossess the Great Souls of Fourbeings:Seath the Scaleless, the Dragon TraitorGravelord Nito, First of the DeadBed of Chaos, Mother of Demonsand the Four Kings (evil ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s!)By harvesting the great Souls of thesefour beings and slaying them, Killer'sConscience reveals that the Lordvesselcan open the doors to a mythic place,the KILN OF THE FIRST FLAME, whereyour chosen discipline of combat, be itsword and shield, bow and arrow, magicuser or high-speed dagger thief will beput to the ultimate test against theinsane GWYN, LORD OF CINDER HIMSELF!"Why are you telling me all this?" You askKiller's Conscience, and he gives a tired,but understanding smile. "We have beenenemies since we met in that game filled with dinosaurs, Starboy Coldheart..." Hestarts, turning to leave. You look over asKiller's Conscience continues. "But I've hadenough of seeing the woman we love dieand die again.""...are you saying there are other worlds,Conscience? That they-""Yeah, Starboy. There are other worldsthrough these games." Killer's Consciencesays, looking you square in the eye beforelooking at the Lordvessel. "That... that isthe key. Finish DARK SOULS... and make thechoice between the two endings, Starboy.""...and then?""Then... you will know what to do, StarboyColdheart." You motion again to Killer'sConscience. "Wait! what did you meanbefore... that you loved Summer-Rain too? Your version of her, I mean?" Killer's Conscience looks pained now, contemplating his service to your main enemy, Mr. Hollywood."I loved her with all my heart, Starboy.Now finish DARK SOULS, and do what youwant to do... travel to find the last worldwhere Summer-Rain still lives... because inalmost all of our worlds... she's gone. Usethe Lordvessel... and don't make the samemistake that I did.""Alright. Thank you, Conscience... for morethan you know." He gestures to you with asweep of his hand, dismissing his own rolein the universe. "Think nothing of it." he sneers at himself."...what happened to her in your universe?""What else, Starboy? I chose to darken theworld in my playthrough of DARK SOULS.I killed her.I killed my Samara Rayne."DARK SOULSPREPARE TO DIE EDITION.

content:
ry 4, 2016
												F#cking Dark Souls, God damn it. When the game came out years ago, I was tasked to make a review of it, and I bashed the game so God damn hard. However, over the time, some of it's issues got fixed, while others seem more or less forgetable. Is the game good? Well... It's more or less a "flawed master-piece". As usual though, I'll start with the bad stuff of the game.The biggest issue on the game, something that has stayed over the years, is the fact that the PC port is a piece of crap. Now follow me on this, it wasn't a piece of crap before, but rather an ENTIRE crap. After a few years of the Games  For Windows Live release, the devs FINALLY NOTICED how bad it was, and since GFWL sort of died, they ported it fully into Steam, and fixed SOME of it's issues. However, the game still performs badly in some PC's, while playing with a keyboard is a sadistic experience. You NEED a controller. And it also doesn't help that all text and tips ingame show Xbox360 controller buttons. EDIT: I also forgot to mention Blight-Town, an area of the game. F#ck my #sshole sideways, that place still has insane frame-rate drops and plays like crap today. Avoid it at all costs. You can infact avoid most of it by getting the Master Key at the start AND I SERIOUSLY SUGGEST YOU DO THE SAME. IT EVEN HAS SOME FPS DROPS ON CONSOLE FOR F#CK SAKE!The second issue on it, is the multiplayer. Now, if you have played this game, I will ask you to read this to the end before bashing this review. It's fun and inmersive, but it's also broken as hell. To begin with, there's quite the amount of hackers roaming arround the game, some of them are nice and only modified their character in a cosmetic point. Others though, have unlimited HP, unlimited stamina, and even broken items that are not supposed to be used, like the infamous Instant-Curse sword. Of course it's fun when you manage to kill them, like I did already a ton of times (will put one of my videos about it under this text), but most of the time you'll die because of the hacks. 


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



The other part of the broken multiplayer is something that I've also decided to exploit, and study how broken it was. There is some sort of level system when you invade, meaning that if you're level 100 it's not possible to invade someone of level 10 in normal ways. However, you can play the entire game at low levels, get insane gear and then come back to low level areas to EXTERMINATE other players in literally one hit, even through their shields because of their low stats. I literally started as Pyromancer, leveled up to lvl13, went through the game like that, farmed Giantdad set (except double Black-Flame, haven't yet gone NG+), and went through the Undead Parish killing people (and a ton of hackers) for days. And I was not the only guy doing it. For what I know, it's sort of fixed in Dark Souls 2, but the devs did nothing to avoid that in DK1, so you should AVOID multiplayer at low levels, or get ready to get completely annihilated. EDIT: I also did a video on that as well, forgot to put it here:


YouTube™ Video:  

			Views: 0		



Another issue I have is more or less with the community. Guys, let's sit down for a minute here and talk about this: Dark Souls IS NOT DIFFICULT. It's not. It's a fair game with fair difficulty. The issue is that most OTHER GAMES are TOO EASY, hold your hand too much. If you trully want difficult games, there's way better ones than this one. Dark Souls is a game where you are supposed to think before you act, not another of those casul games where you just run straight ahead, eat lead and then hide for 8 seconds until the blood of your screen cleans up. If you die, it's 90% of the times YOUR fault, the other 10% being unpatched bugs, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC controls, broken multiplayer or bad network.The last issue is something that a lot of people will sadly experience, and it's the fact that while it's cool that the game does not hold your hand at all, once outside the tutorial area you will NOT know where the f#ck you're supposed to go. The game doesn't trully give you any direction (except for the Firelink crestfallen NPC, but his hints ain't really that helpful and he will move from there midway the game anyway). That means you'll have to explore, and most likely you will go the wrong way, and face enemies WAY tougher than the enemies you're supposed to be facing at the moment, which will utterly f#ck the living sh#t out of you. A map could've been cool, and it wouldn't kill the inmersion of the PLAYER ITSELF (or the character) was the one drawing it.That being said, the game is quite fun, once you go over those problems. It's really inmersive, and it's one of those kind of games were you can find a ton of different ways to get over a problem. The amount of variety in weapons, armor, spells and items is quite great, and seriously beats other games such as Skyrim, where most items are the same  but with slightly higher stats and different graphics. Here, most weapons feel unique, although some of them like the Pickaxe really suck in all kinds of ways. You can also upgrade weapons into different kinds of stats and even upgrade them into new, special weapons, most of them from fallen bosses.The gameplay, ignoring bugs and such is solid. You trully feel like it's a dangerous place, and trully feel in control. You can build your own character, your own playstyle, and even go through the bosses in whatever dumb order you feel like.The lore is there. It's explained through item descriptions (something I find dumb, but it kind of works out) and NPC's, which are GREAT.The multiplayer, ignoring the fact that it was some huge flaws, is also quite fun. Is the game being too difficult on your casul butt? You can summon random players from other parts of the world into your game, to aid you through the area and beat the boss. However to do so, you need to be human, and being human also allows other random players to INVADE your game, and hunt you down. There are different covenants based upon the multiplayer aspect, although if you're playing alone and leaving the multiplayer aside, you won't give a crap about them.The character creation system is also hilariously broken, allowing the player to, if you so desire, create some seriously disgusting abominations as your character.In the end, it's a good game, and I do recommend it. However, you should only play it if you enjoy a fair challenge, like RPG-Action games, AND HAVE A WORKING CONTROLLER. Without a controller, the game is literally unplayable. I ended up picking it up for 5€ on a sale, and for that price it's a solid purchase.Just remember though, THE LEGEND WILL NEVER DIE.I also made a video time ago about my first serious playthrough (the first one was in PC at release and I couldn't even bring myself to finish it, a year later I played it on Xbox360, where I had fun), showing that the game ain't really that difficult and it's actually a ton of fun, highlighting the best moments. It's filled with spoilers though, be aware of that.

content:
ber 6, 2014
												THE EMPEROR'S NEW GROOVE is the funniest movie that I have seen in years. I initially had passed on watching it in the theater because I thought it looked childish, but was convinced to give it a try now that it was out on video. Boy, was my initial impression wrong.The story revolves around a selfish prince who is turned into a llama by one of his subjects. With the help of a kindly peasant he attempts to regain his throne, and in the process finds there's more to him than he previously thought or wanted there to be. While the moral is a good one, it really plays a secondary role to the comedy, which is literally non-stop. GROOVE takes the rapid-fire humor that Disney perfected in Aladdin and combines it with cartoon-style hijinx, the wit of David Spade, and a hilarious lack of reverence for the traditional Disney animated genre. Spade plays his role to perfection, and luckily never crosses the line into being obnoxious. Seinfeld fans are in for a treat, as Puddy plays a very special side-kick role. You really can't take your eyes off the screen for a minute, because you're guaranteed to miss a gag of some sort. The humor works mainly on an adult level, even though kids will be rolling from the funny visuals and some of the more obvious jokes.The DVD itself is a good one. The digital transfer was excellent and the sound quality is top notch. The commentary track is one of the better that I've heard, with interesting and funny insight from all contributors. Animated menus. There's a deleted scene that was probably best left out, but is interesting to watch anyway, plus a few other fun features.In the end, this is one of the best Disney flicks to come along in years. Hardcore Disney fans will eat it up. But even if you're not a fan of Disney's usual animated features you should give GROOVE a shot. Cast aside your pre-concieved notions and you just might be in for a very pleasant surprise. I was. FIVE STARS.

												Seriously, this is one of the best games I ever played. Maybe /the/ best, so far. Why? I have no idea, I started playing, but I gave up, rather quickly, it was just too damn hard.  But then, I tried again and I made progress, where I failed the last time. What a satisfying feeling. And there the fever got me, I wanted to keep playing, to level up, to get the best equipment, or to just see how the next level looks like.But on my way to the End, I cried, I danced in joy, or I was just happy I survive, with my heart racing like I've been running for miles. No game, I ever played, got me so tied up and made me want to play again, no matter how often I died.Some people say, this game has no story, well. On the first glance, there is none. But one of the strengths of Dark Souls, is also it's Story Line, it's hidden. You need to find piece of a puzzle, that you never will truly complete, it gives you hints and you have to make your own story from it. You are in a hostile world, you against everybody else, this just get's underlined by it. Seriously, who can take to die some times and is willing to play a game, where you aren't the Literal God of War, slaying everybody after a while without any problems. You should give Dark Souls a try. This game is really a jewel in the RPG scene and a title, you shouldn't miss.
