content:
0, 2015
												Not for the weak or faint of heart, "casuls" beware, this game will eat you alive!!No really though, Dark Souls is an amazing game that has so much to offer but in the same time, you get what you put into this game. it will challenge you in every way a game can possibly challenge you, it will challenge your patience, it will challenge your determination, it will challenge your attention to detail, it will punish you for every stupid decision you make, and will reward you for the smart decisions you make. It will make you feel small and defeated at times, but when you keep coming back for more and finally succeed, there's such a strong sense of accomplishment with your victories. Dark Souls isn't your traditional "Quest Line" kind of RPG. The game gives you little to no direction, the game wants you to use your brain and figure it out YOURSELF. Dark Souls has a very "indirect" way of telling its story, through NPC conversations, world design changes, and item descriptions. It's very heavy in lore and its actually really interesting and well thought out. The game also draws very heavy influence in its design from the Manga/Anime "Berserk". Dark Souls is a game I would recommend to only the most hardcore of gamers, it can and will run circles around you, I know it may sound like "Why the F*** would I play a game like that?", but trust me, through the challenge, there is a very rewarding and memorable experience to be had. I love the souls series to death, truly special and inspiring game series, probably the most revolutionary game series in modern gaming. Seriously, I can't stress enough how much this game is amazing on all levels. Very creative and mysterious story and lore, interesting and unique interconnected world, extremely in-depth and well balanced statistical combat mechanics that are literally broken down to a science, loads of content, loads of mysterious secret items and game mechanics, loads of really cool viable weapons, loads of different kinds of armor/sets with differentiating perks, rewarding but difficult challenges, Truly unique signature online mechanics, dedicated cultish online community, like literally Dark Souls seriously--HAS IT ALL. In 20+ years of gaming, It is one of the greatest and most complete video game experiences I've ever had. It is the existing proof that the challenging old-school game influence can still thrive in modern day video games.10/10   "A truly amazing masterpiece, a once in a life time game that any true gamer should definitely experience"Fun Fact: I bought this game on a Steam sale, the best $6.79 I've ever spent lolWell if you decide to give Dark Souls a try, don't cry like a B****, man up (or woman up?) and "Git Gud" you filthy casul!!!******** I HIGHLY recommend a controller for Dark Souls, this isn't the best of ports and has a very BAD KB+M setup but in all honesty, Dark Souls was truly meant to be played with a controller anyway, which is why i'm sure From Software didn't make KB+M a priority because they know, if you know anything about Dark Souls, you're not gonna use it, you're gonna use a controller. If you try to use KB+M with Dark Souls, You're an idiot and you're gonna get rekt lol

ber 28, 2014
												It reminds me of games from my childhood. Enemies are tough, resources are limited, and you need to be able to get from point A to point B without dying. I spent 4hrs at Capra Demon, defeating him only with the help of a kind soul (that soul later invaded me and tried to kill me, but I shut that sucker down). If you die, you have to restart at the last checkpoint and kill everything all over again. If you use a resource and you die, you don't get that resource back. Enemies are tough enough and fight well enough that you actually have to know how to fight and how to defend yourself in order to survive. As frustrating as this game is, it's extremely satisfying and fulfilling to overcome a challenging enemy. Remember that game from your childhood where you spent so much time trying to get through one area? Remember how you felt when you finally beat it? You'll get that same feeling in Dark Souls.

content:
, 2015
												One of the best games I've ever played. When this came out on the 360, I had no media knowledge of it (I recommend this for most hyped games) and came in completely blind. I got my ♥♥♥ kicked up and down because I thought it was a hack and slasher, obviously there is that but its much more controlled and precise. Pros:Level design - There are hardly any loading screens during the entire playthrough of this game, maybe a handful. The first 75% of the game is chock full of beautiful interconnected environments, and you will not get tired of running through them when you inevitably die :)Combat - Very visceral and precise. You will be punished harshly for using the last of your stamina and missing that risky shot. There is dodging and rolling which give you the tools to dance around your enemies if you are skilled, but even a skilled player can easily be overwhelmed by an over aggressive group of enemies. One of the best parts of the game.Enemies - Great variety of enemies and bosses, both challenging enough to not get tired out quickly.Online play - Theres nothing besides boss fights that gets my heart pumping like my world getting invaded. These invasions keep you on your toes and give you such a rush when you kill your invader as well. The messages and summoning are also great aspects of the online play, with overused and sometimes witty messages popping up to describe the levels around you. If you find an area to hard, summon a friend! Unfortunately summoning in some places is hard because there simply aren't enough players to find (especially within certain level ranges) to summon for a boss. Each boss is definitely killable via solo, but O&S boss will be tough if you cant find a co-op partner.Dying actually matters in this game as well, so the sense of riskiness is always present when holding a large amount of souls and youre trying to decide whether or not to cash them in or save up more.Cons:Framerate - The framerate can get a little bogged down sometimes, especially in Blighttown. It was way worse on the 360 though.The last sections of the game feel rushed and are not nearly as good as the rest (75%) of the game. This is not a huge con though because for the most part its great.Lack of summoning in some places due to lower player counts is somewhat of a negative, especially if youre having a hard time with the boss.All in all this game is a must buy for RPG fans, if you dont own it and youi call yourself one then please revoke your badge until its in your library :)

												A great game that brings back a nostalgia of retro games where your not hand held or pampered with helpful tips, equipment or directions in the beginning. All you understand is to move forward and expect the unexpected. On a side note, the freaking tutorial is a boss fight that I did not understand how to beat until I saw the opening to an exit to get a sword and shield. An appreciation on not just on what it delivers, but for the players who traverse through the undead burg or  through the sewers of the depths and onwards to blighttown or Anor Londo, the experience is like no other. Each environment is a unique set piece with its own enemies and pathways to take. I remember reaching the firelink shrine the very first time and unknowingly heading down towards the New Londo Ruins only to be demolished by ghosts. This gives you a fair warning that your not equipped to travel through the area yet, but a bit sight seeing of what to expect later in the game can always help your conscience.Finally, the boss battles are some of the most exciting and frustrating thing about playing this game. Patience is key and learning the patterns and weakness of the enemy can go a long way. I've found sometimes even the mini bosses can be a handful because they can surprise you when entering a room and rush you unknowingly. Although I may have started playing this game at the latter end of its release (not even a quarter of the way through), I will definitely be looking forward to preordering Dark Souls 2 for the PC. content:
3, 2015
												With GFWL removed, I think that this game is now at its best on PC. Chances are that you've heard of Dark Souls, and that someone you know may play it/have played it, so what's all the hype about?Dark Souls is an atmospheric action RPG which brings back the dungeon crawling of oldschool games like Ultima Underworld. Dark Souls, I think, though, does a much better job at making these tried and true mechanics interesting due to great design work and ideas, an amazing, engrossing atmosphere, interesting lore, the best world/level design that I have EVER SEEN in a video game, and solid gameplay.Dark Souls' gameplay is quite simple to grasp, but there are plenty of intricacies which you can explore. It's a third-person action game, with a slow, calculated speed. Combat in Dark Souls is, no matter what people say, usually more about what you decide to do and when you decide to do it, and less about the twitch reaction times and such seen in faster action games. Combat is fleshed out through a bevy of customisation and character development options, and I'd like to summarise these. When it comes to dealing with damage, you have three options. Tank up with a ridiculous amount of armour, but hinder your rolling (not viable for most of the game), use a good shield to block damage, or roll past or through attacks, either using your positioning or the invincibility frames in the roll to avoid the attacks. There are countless weapons with varying movesets, statistical attributes, lore, origins and appearances, and you'll honestly be spoiled for choice. Not to mention, you can even use boss souls to create boss weapons, and use the same move set that a boss used. In fact, most enemy movesets are analagous to yours, and this is something lovely about Dark Souls' combat. It is fair. You and your average humanoid enemy die similarly quickly, have a similar or even equal moveset, and the same tools, they can even heal. The difference is that you are smart and skilled. The melee combat in general is incredibly fleshed out, and it feels realistic and satisfying. An example of said realism is that, if you have only 66% of the required strength for a weapon, you can use it two-handed, but not one-handed.Most enemies, though, don't have magic, and there are three schools of magic in Dark Souls; Miracles, Sorceries, and Pyromancies, each of these schools have a lore-based origin and associated areas and NPCs, and they each differ greatly in function and associated playstyle. Miracles are governed by faith, and provide healing, utility, and with a few spells, huge lightning damage. The caveat of said damage spells, though, is the low amount of uses. Basically in Dark Souls, there is no Mana/MP bar, and each spell simply has a limited amount of uses. Sorceries are governed by intelligence, and are the most versatile school of magic, and you can easily build a character to use sorceries exclusively, and nearly ignore melee weapons, sorceries are simple and have a high amount of uses. Sorceries also, however have a few utility spells related to stealth and subterfuge. Pyromancy is different to Sorceries and Miracles in that the spells aren't governed by any attributes, and don't have intelligence or faith requirements for the spells. Pyromancy is a wild, fluid school of magic, with close range blasts, strange modifications to oneself and one's environment, gravity-affected fireballs and deadly firestorms. Pyromancy's strength is governed solely by the strength of one's Pyromancy Flame, which can be upgraded through spending currency with certain NPCs, and it is by far the easiest to get into. Pyromancy, however, does require one to get much closer and personal than other schools, and unlike sorceries and miracles, Pyromancy does not have any weapon or armour buffs.To summarise the gameplay, it starts off as the humble set of tools which you use to journey through the harsh, incredibly unforgiving world of Lordran, but in New Game + and subsequent playthroughs, it turns into a lovely set of mechanics with immense customisation, just waiting for you to experiment and try new builds.The game has multiplayer, too, mainly accessed through faction-like covenants, and there are two 'fields' of multiplayer interaction; 'Malicious Interaction' ,and 'Helpful Interaction'.'Helpful Interaction' consists of co-op in strangers' worlds, and leaving helpful messages. 'Malicious Interaction' consists of tricking players, or invading their game and killing them. The line is blurred with some interactions, though.Of course, done with the intricacies of the gameplay, it's time to address the elephant in the room. The difficulty. Dark Souls is infamous for its difficulty, but it is NOT the school of difficulty which wants to laugh in your face with an elitist attitude. Dark Souls' difficulty is there because you and your character must face immense hardship in this world, trying again and again to get through a hard boss battle, or an absurdly difficult area, or past one ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ enemy, and when you do succeed, and when you do get through, you will feel great. The difficulty will no doubt make you die countless times, but Dark Souls is NOT a trial and error game. The design is for the most part, incredibly fair, with any ambushes, enemies or traps being forewarned or visible before they can possibly put the player in danger. Now, a certain platform before two ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ archers is a bit unfair, as is one alley beatdown in a certain another area, but in general, the game follows every 'good game design principle' in the book.I said that the level and world design of Dark Souls were the best I've ever seen in a video game, and I can't stress that enough. Nearly every noticeable area you see in Dark Souls WILL be visited later, even the small tower in the distance, or the insignificant forest below you, or the broken down slums beneath you, you go everywhere you could possibly want to go in Lordran and more. This isn't even mentioning how well the world fits together. A significant area in the game is placed between another significant area, which you look down on, and another, secret area, which you also look down on. While in the depths of one area, you can look all the way up and see the previous area. The sense of internal consistency and continuity is incredibly strong, and the attention to detail put into this world is great. When it comes to the actual level design, the game is still solid. Each level fits its respective setting/theme, with levels looping around on themselves, opening up shortcuts, being spatially navigated however the player sees fit, with the bosses being fought in the most interesting arenas every time, the actual level design is bliss.The story and plot of Dark Souls is grand and depressing, which adds to the oppressive atmosphere of hardship which the game gives off in all other aspects. I'm not going to spoil any of it here, but your goal is quite clear. In terms of lore, there are so many interesting stories in the lore and environment, about the characters and history and locations. The game a;sp manages to appeal to emotion so well, with nearly no melodrama, in a way that few other games do.The game is nearly perfect, but there are a few flaws, mainly brought about because the game was rushed out the door. A few great ideas for NPC interactions were scrapped, the online connectivity is imperfect due to a system with multiple servers managing multiple varying P2P connections, and a select few areas were clearly rushed to meet a deadline. Also, I'd say that some areas in the latter half of the game fail to keep the perfect pace maintained in the first half. But in the end, Dark Souls doesn't disappoint.Dark Souls is a modern classic. You absolutely MUST experience what this game offers, and play it until the very end of the storyline. It's an entirely unique RPG which is fully fleshed out in nearly every way.

content:
r 10, 2015
												Excellent game!Note: This is an actual game, not a movie posing as a game. People get confused since this isn't your typical interactive movie. It will challenge you, which, is what games do.If you really want to, there are two built-in easy buttons.1) You can simply out level everything and power your way through bosses.2) Summon help. The AI was not designed for multiple players.Cons: The leveing system. FromSoftware should stop using a leveling system. The leveling idea is an anachromism left over from pencil & paper roleplaying games. It existed to make up for a lack of game play mechanics to differentiate inexperienced from experienced. Dark Souls has loads of game mechanics where you develop real skill and experience. Leveling also creates this limiting summoning experience. There's a level window for summoning and invading in each area. If your not within that level window, no Jolly Co-op for you!

Dark Souls: Prepare To Die EditionThis is by far the best game I have ever played in a long time, everything about it is perfect and keeps me playing for hours.  But it didn't start like that. Death after death to the first boss made me want to stop playing, but I didn't, I kept trying and trying until I found out what I was doing wrong. You will spend the whole game dying, learning from your mistakes, and feeling proud of yourself once you've mastered a fight and beat a boss.  All I can say is don't get discouraged, the game will get easier the more you play, trust me.  I used to suck and now im on NG+8 and I don't suck as much anymore. :D10/10 Dark Souls Best Game

content:
er 14, 2016
												This game is dated, slow, and can't run properly without installing a mod. That being said, this game great. It's a fun ARPG that puts your skills to the ultimate test. Yes, this game is hard. Yes, you will die. Yes, it's kinda the point. Every death you learn about the game. That boss that dunked you with his buttslam attack you didn't know he had? Now you know he has it. That well-hidden boulder trap that rolled down the stairs to crush you? Now you know where to find it, and when to run. The challenge is there, but so is the knowledge and learning to overcome it with your own power.Any RPG character you want to make, you can probably make it here. Poison Fist Monk? Spell slinging Magic Knight? Zweihander Champion of the Giants? Fire breathing, ninja flipping Dragon-Ninja hybrid? Check, check, check, and after grinding to get Dragon Scales, check!The visuals in the game are awesome. The enemy, level, and boss design feels unique and original in each area you visit. Blighttown is a toxic swamp of gloom and despair, Anor Londo is as prestigious and clean as it is controller breaking. The lighting bolt spitting snake people in Sen's Fortress. The greataxe wielding Taurus Demons of Lost Izalith. Gravelord Nito is terrifying, Ornstein and Smough are badass and powerful, and Artorias of the Abyss is one of the best bosses I've ever fought in a video game. They're all there to kill you and look cool doing so.The game rewards exploration as well. There are tons of side paths and secret areas that lead to weapon upgrades, new spells, and extra souls to level yourself with. If a boss is too hard, try another path in the area. Grind up some souls, maybe you'll find a new weapon to bash their brains in with!If the game really is too hard, try some Jolly Co-operation with a friend! I actually find the game more fun (and less brutal to my blood-pressure) when I tear down a naked-demon-spider-queen together with a friend.I've finished three playthroughs of the game (two co-op, one solo). My two major complaints are the lack of dual wielding and the game not running at 60fps (Dark Souls HD Remaster Fromsoft please please please). You CAN dual-wield weapons, but it's not very good in this game. Thankfully the sequel fixes that.TL;DR: Game is hard. Game is fun.

er 23, 2016
“I just wanted to see the plot” - kasuparuBRIGHT SOULS: Prepare to Smile Edition1. I am a casualI don’t play games because they are challenging. I want games to have the plot, thoughts or feelings for me. After 100 hours of play I discovered that Dark Souls is about overcoming own inability and impatience. Player character power depends on player’s ability and skill. You learn to be calm and try again. This reminded me of the race mission in Mafia: The City of Lost Heaven before the patch came out. I learned how to drive in 2 weeks. The patch lowered the difficulty, and added the Skip button. Casuls.2. “Do it with a RockBand controller, then we’ll talk”I played using mouse and keyboard. Developers of DSFix and DSMFix made it possible, huge thanks! It is much more comfortable for me, and allows to control the camera at the speed and precision I want to. I almost never used camera lock-on on an enemy. Lock-on makes you move slower, and the camera messes up if the target dashes or jumps. If there is anyone telling you to use the controller, disregard, and play the way you want.3. Check or FoldI did not like how the game increases stakes by promoting to be human. I was hollow most of the times, soloed all bosses. On the bright part, I was never invaded. I used guides a lot. Did not spoil anything for me, the game is still challenging.Top-3 hardest bosses (NG): Capra & Dogs, Ornstein & Smough, Artorias & RNG.Top-3 locations I hate: Tomb of the Giants, Blighttown, Duke’s Archives.I blazed through New Game+, enjoying New Game++ or another run.

												So I was walking around the burg when a van drove up next to me.  The driver stopped the vehicle and spoke to me, asked if I would like to earn some souls through what he called 'jolly co-operation'.  Being new, and in desperate need of the SL, I graciously accepted the offer.  He gave me some white key and told me to go around to the back of the van and unlock it.  Upon doing so, he suddenly burst out and attacked me.  I jumped away, trying to strike back, but the man easily parried my blow, riposting back with a hard fist to my gut.  Crumpling to my knees, he then kicked me down and rolled me onto my stomach, then proceeding to backstab me over and over again with his estus flask, arms outstretched above his head, shouting out PRAISE THE SUN! between ragged breaths.  It was the worst experience of my life.10/10

												Much have been said about this game's difficulty, and while it is hard, it's not impossible and is rarely unfair. It has a deep combat system that's precise, easy to pick up, but takes time to master. It's set in one of the best designed worlds in video games; Lordran. A mysterious and often beautiful world that at the same time can overwhelm you with fear. How the areas in this world interconnects is just mind-bending genius. There are so many ways to play this game that it never gets old no matter how many times you play through it. A masterwork.

content:
, 2014
												I played this game all the way through the first non-tutorial boss. this includes a big detour fighting some skeletons in a graveyard for about an hour before my friend told me that those things should have been killing me and I was supposed to go the other way. Basically the whole thing is a giant patience test, where the only way you ever die is by being greedy and wanting to end an encounter sooner by getting more hits in. When the only way you can lose is if you're anxious for the central gameplay to be over with sooner, there's something seriously wrong in the game's design.If this game is challenging, it's after the first boss, who I beat on the first try because he telegraphed everything like mad.If this game is atmospheric, it's after the first boss, because I just had generic medieval castle to go through.If this game is rich or deep in story, it's after the first boss (and an NPC who talks to you a while afterward), because I still have no idea what the series is about or how anything is supposed to work (including a lot of gameplay elements, for which there is no written information anywhere - wiki walks are fine for sandbox games but just annoying in a beat 'em up).If a game doesn't give me a reason to play it by the end of the first real area, then either it has nothing to offer, or it's stringing me along instead of respecting me as a customer. Either way DS1 was a huge letdown and I really don't get all the hype.In a word, the game is "tedious", and I'm amazed at how many people seem to confuse that with "difficult". It's difficult to force yourself to play in a way that will win, because you'd rather play in a way that seems fun but gets you killed. This is not the kind of difficult that a video game is supposed to be.Pick it up on sale as a casual time-killer but look elsewhere if you want a game that actually wants you to have fun. If you're looking for a challenge in the same general genre, I recommend Rogue Legacy.

content:
er 28, 2014
												Before I begin, I would like to point out that I bought this game originally a couple years ago on Xbox 360, before I decided to get into PC gaming. I easily have over a thousand hours in this game on Xbox, and although I come back to this game often on PC now days, I have played it SO much that there is nothing new left for me. This game is, in my opinion, probably the BEST aRPG ever made.......EVER!There are many amazing things about this game, that I will list here:* The amount of character customization is staggering.* The fighting mechanics are arguably unmatched by ANY other game.* The story is very deep and full of lore. It is in NO WAY thrown in your face, in fact it's quite the opposite, in that you will need to literally search through every item description and NPC conversation, in order to figure out what is happening in this decrepit land known as Lordran.* Monster Design is arguably unmatched by any other game* After you have played through the game multiple times, Dark Souls' PvP adds a whole new layer of replayability to the game, easily adding many more hours of enjoyment to the game. * PvP is actually mixed in with PvE, in that other players can 'Invade' your world if certain conditions are met, and this greatly adds to the feeling of hopelessness and despair that the Developers have masterfully crafted into this game. There's so much more about this game that is literally too hard to put into words. I just ask that if you give this game a chance, (you better!) that you ACTUALLY give this game a chance. It will seem awkward, or hard at first. You will die, but if you can push through the first couple areas in this game, you will become addicted, I guarantee it. The only Cons that I see PC gamers taking issue with would be:* KB/M controls are broken, making a controller strongly recommended. However, there are mods that help fix this. * If you buy and install this game, it will NOT run correctly on any PC unless you also download and install DSFIX. [www.nexusmods.com] You MUST download and install this, and the 5 minutes it takes to do so fixes the game. * There are not many options for graphics in the game itself, however, exploring the .ini files included in DSFIX will provide any PC gamer with many of the graphics options that we are used to. Please do not take these cons as a reason not to buy and play this game, you would literally be missing out on the BEST aRPG ever made. Seriously, just buy it already! :D

content:
er 23, 2016
												One of the most intimidating games that i played so far. Dark Souls is an interesting game that its praised for its difficulty, but thats what makes it a great game, since overcoming those obstacles that the game puts you constantly makes you feel overwhelmingly satisfied. The most interesting thing about this game is its meaning since its very similar to real life and it has very interesting philosophical concepts. Its hard to pinpoint what truly is since every player experience it differently and its open for interpretation, and the story is hidden. Though the most common philosophy i can find is existentialism. By that i mean that not everything has meaning in Dark Souls. The player starts as a hollow, which is a state that a being is cursed and will not die and the Undead slowly lose their mind and consciousness. In order to become human they need humanity or else they delve deep into madness and pain. Humanity makes you into a human form but every time you reverse the hollowing you lose some part of your self (existence). For me the hollow-human state resembles a lot with Albert Camus "The Myth of Sisyphus", since how much you try to escape or in this case to die peacefully you can't, and then comes the realization of the absurd. Just like Sisyphus you are destined to progress through the world (Lordran) and discover some kind of meaning if there is any. Another thing about hollow state or rather Dark Souls itself is an allegory for depression. Dark Souls in general is a very depressive and sad game but the hollow state is a resemblance to it since the more you go hollow (feel pain, sadness, sorrow, misery and not doing anything about it) the more you lose your self in depression. The game makes a good example on how you should progress and fight this state of mind just like in real life to overcome all the difficulties and hard times that we are faced.The NPC's in this game have all really sad stories(and most of them die and you are unable to save them) which makes you feel very compassionate, and understand their suffering. To dwell more on my interpretation a good example is a NPC called Solaire which has a quest to find the Sun(The Sun as a metaphor for hope and meaning), but the more you progress in the game you will see that Solaire is losing his hope and will to fulfill his quest to find his Sun and slowly becomes hollow(you can save him but he is still affected). The story is hidden in Dark Souls and you have to read item descriptions to learn something about the lore of this game. The design is one of the best aspect in this game since everything is interconnected and that makes it to be a more immersive experience. Also the game has a PvE and PvP aspect hence becoming a human will activate the PvP and you might get invaded more often in your game world, but another interesting thing is that by playing the game your character feels lonely and everything is against you, helping someone in PvP for a boss or from an invader is very satisfactory and the game encourages cooperation more. Though the most interesting aspect i find for this game is that it doesn't make you important(rarely for a video game to do that), rather you are there like many others who ventured in that unwelcome world to find their meaning or to simply don't go hollow.This game was a present surprise and i really enjoyed it, i recommend it to everyone who wants to play a meaningful game. In short:Pros:+Gameplay +Design+Immersion+Difficulty+SoundCons:-Capped 30 fps (Needs DSFix)-For those using mouse (Needs dsmfix)

number of helpful: 11 of 17 people (65%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
2016
												Dark Souls will be remembered as a masterpiece that dared to go back to gaming’s roots and doing so perfectly. Away with regenerating health, minimaps and other forms of handholding. Lordran is an unforgiving world that wants you to take risk and learn from its brutal nature. The game will kill you… a lot. But as you die you will learn and eventually die a little less and overcome its obstacles giving you a fulfilling feeling of accomplishment. In other words Dark Souls is a hard game. But that’s due to its unforgiving nature that punishes every mistake if you don’t play by its rules. I played it on PS3 and even though the port has some obvious issues, I have enjoyed it just as much. This game is still a gem, and I can only encourage anyone to give it a fair try.

content:
, 2016
Review in one sentenceA very fun and challenging game, a one of its kind and a must-try.Gaming BackgroundI'm a PC gamer who predominantly plays FPS games, but has played a bit of MOBA and RTS too. Before I picked up Dark Souls, the only games I had ever played with a controller date back to the 6th generation consoles. I decided to give Dark Souls a go seeing as I finally got myself a controller and my friends were insisting I did.Index of this review Difficulty is Fun  Lore & Level Design A port of a console game Unnecessarily secretive Final wordsDifficulty is FunThough this game is notorious for its difficulty, it's challenging in a fair way; there isn't any RNG that determines whether you live or die. This game is hard because it's skill based.In a lot of RPGs, your character becomes stronger through leveling. Often this means you can both dish out and sustain orders of magnitude more damage than before. In Dark Souls, while you can definitely level your character to some extent, the real difference between you at level 1 and you at level 80 is raw skill. That's what makes this game so uniquely fun. You overcome the opponents not because your stats say you do; you overcome them because you've died to them a couple times and you now understand what you've been doing wrong all this time. This is where the phrase "git gud" comes from. Proof of this is that some players have been able to beat the game with a lvl 1 character, or without healing a single time.The always-on autosave feature in this game means that mistakes are permanent. Although this sounds hardcore, it's important to understand that dying is an important part of the game, and you lose less on death than in most games. Your "souls", which is both the in-game currency and the unit of XP you can use to level up and upgrade weapons, are dropped on the spot where you died.Lore & Level DesignDark Souls is made by FROM software, a Korean game developer, and it shows. The lore is akin to Asian folklore rather than the Greek, Norse, or Biblical stuff we're used too. This makes the lore unique and refreshing. Personally, the lore hasn't been able to rub off on me that much. It's hard to understand and hasn't really succeeded in giving me a sense of purpose, or part of something huge.That said, there's something uniquely captivating about Dark Souls. Its level design deserves an honorable mention, because it has somehow succeeded making 90% of the game contingent on each other. This means you can walk from the starting area to the rest of the world without loading screens or cutscenes. But it doesn't stop there; they have managed to meticulously interconnected their world in a brilliant way. Time and time again you will find yourself bewildered, exclaiming: "This elevator leads back here!? Holy crap!"In another stroke of genius, they decided to leave music out of the game almost entirely. They mean to make the atmosphere feel solitary and desolate, which they've done a pretty decent job at. On top of all this, it looks pretty decent for a 2011 game.A port of a console gameIn this part I'll be talking about some technical downsides that I feel stem mostly from the fact that this game is a PC Port from a 2011 console game. By default the framerate is capped at 30fps. Popular community made mods allow you to bump this up to 60, but at certain costs. This is the type of game engine where the graphical framerate is linked to the game's calculations. This means that the game will behave slightly differently at 60fps, yuck.The online connectivity is can be finnicky and might require community mods to work to your liking as well. It's not the most stable or reliably built game in the world, basically.Unnecessarily secretiveMy biggest gripe with this game is how it doesn't bother explaining new players a lot of their complicated mechanics. Don't get me wrong! The fact that this came doesn't spam you with popups saying "Press R2 to parry!" is mostly a good thing. The game's minimalistic HUD and GUI contribute to its unique atmosphere, but this is a double-edged blade.It takes most players a good while to figure out what Humanity is, how it works, what the number in your top bar means and what it means to be hollowed. To tell you the truth I still only understand how it works, but not why it works. I could go on and on listing bits of information or entire game mechanics that remain poorly-, mis-, or even unexplained throughout the game. This would all be fine in 1999, where the kid next door would tell you how to unlock a cool sword. But alas, we're in the era where extensive libraries of this type of information is at your fingertips. Sadly, at times this game almost beckons you to whip up the wiki, because decisions are permanent and you might not want to make any mistakes.The best way to play this game is by having an enthousiastic friend you can approach for specific questions, but will not tell you all of the ins and outs of the game.Summary and Final Words- Very enjoyable and rewarding gameplay- Looks decent, with great character & level design- Unique and myserious, sometimes to a faultNo matter what kind of player you are, you would be doing yourself a disservice by not at least trying this game. If you have any comments, questions, or critiques, feel free to add me on Steam. I'll even help you with the game if you want.

content:
ry 24, 2015
												If the horror stories are to be believed, Dark Souls is a punishing game that only those with infinite patience will ever see the end of. As with so many legends, there’s a grain of truth to these claims that’s been exaggerated out of proportion; yes, Dark Souls is a merciless beast whose demanding nature will put off a lot of people. But is it insurmountable for the average gaming enthusiast? I’d argue no.After a cryptic intro that raises more questions than it answers, Dark Souls places you in a prison cell armed with only a broken sword. On top of that, your character died before you even had a say in their life. All this sets the tone for an adventure that pulls no punches, and by the time you find a decent weapon you’ll have already run into some lethal creatures. But there’s nothing inherently unreasonable about the opening segment of gameplay; you’re told what buttons do what, then given a weapon and left to figure out the most efficient means of killing stuff with it. The result is a game that trains you to approach new areas with caution, never underestimate an opponent, and always have an escape route if things go ♥♥♥♥-up. It’s an intriguing hybrid of old and new game design, sans most of the cryptic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ your nostalgia doesn’t let you remember.The combat is the dominant gameplay feature, of course, and I don’t hesitate to call it some of the best I’ve seen: a dagger feels completely different from a giant hammer, and neither can be called definitively better than the other. Dodging attacks and getting backstabs is a legitimate tactic, but so is tanking damage and punching through blocks with heavy weapons, not to mention the abundance of magical options I was too scared to try for a long time. It’s a strategic experience that something like Skyrim can barely dream of unless modded up the wazoo.Speaking of strategy, Dark Souls is one of precious few games that actually give meaningful penalties for death. Every time you die, you lose your accumulated points and have precisely one chance to retrieve them. If you ♥♥♥♥ that up, the points are gone forever. It’s harsh, to be sure, but checkpoints are never obscenely far apart and I learned early on that if you know your downfall is imminent, you might as well try and die in a spot that can be reached easily. It’s just another system to use to your advantage and will only screw you over if you push your luck: know when to retreat and spend your points, rather than lose them deep in enemy territory. That the entire world respawns when you use a checkpoint is bizarre at first, yet makes a lot of sense to me; sitting at a bonfire becomes a tactical decision, since it provides safety at the cost of undoing your progress elsewhere. And as crushing as it is to lose your hard-earned points, those moments are also the best times to throw yourself at a boss or speed through a tough area to grab items.Navigating the metroidvania landscape is the other great art of Dark Souls. Locales are varied (along with their inhabitants) and frequently bigger than they first appear, overflowing with hidden loot, shortcuts and even optional bosses. Backtracking does become a nuisance beyond a certain point, and the teleport option is hard-earned, but the only places I truly dislike are the handful suffering from framerate dips (on consoles) and finicky platform segments. Other than that, I find the game’s setup enjoyable, not least due to its role in one of Dark Souls’ most surprising triumphs: storytelling.There’s a wealth of lore to be found in subtle background details and item descriptions, and it really felt like I was piecing together the world’s history from the clues left behind. The slow realisation of just how boned the land is fits perfectly with the sense of dread pervading the gameplay, and even your character’s ability to rise after death is contextually justified. For a game that could’ve relied solely on its combat, I find it doubly impressive that Dark Souls manages to have a memorable world, and with a minimalistic style that’s refreshing in an industry whose attempts at storytelling often rely on overwritten cutscenes.Another remarkable aspect of Dark Souls is the online integration: players can leave messages that randomly pop up in people’s worlds. Some are helpful, some are amusing, and some are outright lies. Then you have a clunky but workable co-op mechanic, along with the danger of being invaded by other guys whenever you de-zombify yourself. The whole arrangement is seemingly unique to the Souls franchise, and has created a profound sense of community while also reminding you that nobody can be trusted.At its core, Dark Souls represents a raw yet fair challenge where death is almost never anyone’s fault but the player’s. And while your initial perception may be one of cruel chaos, dig deep enough and you’ll find a sense of order. By almost any measure, I think Dark Souls must be called an impressive piece of work. The only question is whether you’ll enjoy an action game which requires you to be methodical and treat every fight like a matter of life and death. Unlike some parts of the fanbase, I understand that it’s possible to not like something for reasons other than sucking at it.

er 29, 2015
												Dark Souls is probably one of my all-time favorite games. It's challenging but fair, features immersive gameplay, interesting lore, a deep combat system, and there are so many viable combat styles that you could play through this game over and over again without it getting stale.This being said, it's not a perfect game. There are some bosses and areas in the second half of the game that are blatantly unfinished, and the netcode can be iffy when it comes to latency, however the good aspects greatly outweigh the poor ones.

I LOVED the game music. I LOVED Dark Souls environment. I LOVED pvp. I LOVED DARK SOULS!! content:
6, 2014
												You will loathe yourself for playing this game. Let me explain: it is the most sadisticly addicting games ever created. Let me furher explain: This game will test your skill as a gamer and you patience as a human being. Its challenges are numerous and seemingly endless. You will die and die and die again then, probably, hurl your remote (or keyboard, I'd highly recomend a remote though) across what ever space you are playing in and swear that you will never play it again... But then like Rihanna you come crawling back begging for more. The worst thing about all of this is that even though it will make you want to rip your teeth out, you'll love every second of it. The feeling of finally figuring out how to beat a challenge is so amazing at times you might feel like throwing a small party in celebration, and the rush you get when beat the game (your tormentor for the past many hours of game play) is even more so. You will be hard pressed to find a gaming experience as thrilling and rewarding as sDark Souls, as soon as you start playing it will become your most hated addiction.

content:
er 17, 2013
												I deleted my old review because I gave it unjustly more than likely due to rage. I've played a good amount, the part i was stuck on was the Tarus Demon and the part after that where it involved a knight and some random hallowed in a pincer attack. After taking a break for many months and then retrying it. I've progressed to the first bell. I don't know what the other reviews state when they ran into bugs, problems and etc. I have an unmodded version and it runs just fine. Sure the mouse/keyboard should be fixed but to be honest I don't mind using a 360 controller. Regardless here is my review.The game will in fact not hold your hand. The will game anally ravage you over and over again over a picket fence. The game is unforgiving. The game will destroy you.But do you know what the good thing about it? Every time I finally over come my rage, calmed down adn thought about it. Thought about how I could improve. Thought about how I was doing something wrong. The more times I tackled it. I got better and better at parrying especially when I went to kill Havel. I felt pride and joy. I feel so happy and better than I even got to the first bell. Now supposely that was the "easy" part of the game as my friends have stated but you know what? I am waiting for the challenges. I played all day on 12/16/2013 perhaps I only made it pass the butterfly moth, the belfry gargoyles and even rang the first bell.I will tell you the game is very hard but can easily overcome with patience and it pays off. You'll feel very accomplished at every victory. If you like a challenge then please get this game and play it. I await for DS 2.The only part I don't get is why you have to follow the laws of physics(aka if you use a long sword and hit a wall while attacking your sword bounces off and your attack doesn't land) but yet the AI can ignore it. Sure it makes it difficult especially since the AI for basic minions can be very stupid and I can see why they would set them to ignore it but perhaps they'll make better AI and you can use your terrian to stop a black knight from swinging while you keep prodding at him or even that he choses not to swing but prod at you rapier style instead of full blow swings. But regardless this part doesn't matter because I usually get a spear and one sword on hand so I can switch as needed rather it's a narrow hallway or not a narrow hallway.Beat the game.... Kinda disappointed at few bosses and kinda disappointed at the ending.... Still a good challenge and I still enjoyed it.

content:
er 28, 2013
												It may be tough, and it may make you cry, but between the scenery and the difficulty, it is a beautiful and challenging game. The detail on the buildings, Anor Londo specifically, is to die for (since the things in the place might kill you anyway!). It is a tough game, for sure, and should not be sat down with while in a mental state that says "I will be good at this, better than anybody else, and I will beat it." You will more than likely end up frustrated in the end. The pc port is iffy, albeit playable (but makes the game a lot harder), but with a controller it's equal to playing the console version of the game. The major downside to this game is that when trying to either invade or summon, it is a hit and miss. You can either get lucky and summon/invade on the first try, or anything that isn't lucky, and be sitting for 30 minutes to an hour trying to summon your friends. (I'm not sure if this also happens when trying to invade.)Overall, the game is great and I can't wait for the second one, which will have better ports!

content:
er 28, 2013
												What can I say about Dark Souls that hasn't been said before?It's fantastic. It's unrelenting, challenging, stimulating and at times, incredibly frustrating. But all of those things are precisely why the game is so great. It doesn't hold your hand. It doesn't let you save whenever you want. It forces you to think and use reasoning. Instead of relying on the game mechanics to save you, you must learn to use it to your advantage. Once you take control, it's an incredibly rewarding experience unmatched by most modern action RPGs. This game will go down in history along with the likes of Elder Scrolls, Final Fantasy and Legend of Zelda.

												Dark Souls é um RPG Dungeon Crawler Hardcore de Hack and Slash de uma jobabildade excecional. O design e arte dos inimigos e masmorras bem como o seu combate são as estrelas deste jogo. Que é díficil mas justo, com um ambiente de fantasia medieval profundo, encantador e mortal. Onde a morte nos espera em cada canto mas que mesmo assim nos convece a ficar lá. É um dos melhores jogos do género. Possuí também uma história mistoriosa e complexa mas coerente e muito bem feita (que tem uma ligação forte ás sequelas). E também um modo de Multijogador (Co-Op e PvP) bastante divertidos.Simplesmente um clássico e uma peróloa de jogo.Dark Souls é suberbo, profundo, encantador, perigoso, dícifil, justo, poderoso, glorioso, coerente, inesquecivel, indispensável e épico!

content:
7, 2015
												With 400+ hours put into the PC version and over 1000+ hours put into the PS3 version I have decided to write a review of Dark SoulsIt's a game developed by From Software who also created Demon Souls and Dark Souls 2. However Dark souls 2 didn't have the same team as Demon Souls and the first Dark Souls, that team instead went on to create Bloodborne. The team behind Demon Souls, Dark Souls, and Bloodborne have planned on creating a third installment of the Dark Souls series and will be released in the near future.Dark Souls probably has one of the heaviest lores of all possible games released. In addition to the lore being heavy it's not even fully explained to the player, instead you must discover this information by reading descriptions and understand the meaning inbetween each area and uncover all of the information behind it. There is many theories when it comes to this game but you should probably search for the information on wikipedias or from YouTubers if you're interested in that.Many people describe this game as a very difficult game with a huge learning curve but I disagree. Yes it's not an easy game however it can be mastered very efficiently pretty quickly. What you must learn is how to roll, block, parry, manage weight (distribute weapons and armor efficiently to make yourself agile but strong enough to kill your opponents), and simply put: not die. The game teaches you the mechanics early on but later never gives hints on what to do because you must teach yourself how to succeed. The sense of victory is what makes this game wonderful. Say you're stuck fighting a certain boss, you simply cannot beat it and you're close to giving up and lay the game aside. Though you have not given up completely, so you give it one more shot. You make it to the fighting area and you remember the countless attempts of you failing. You remember what killed you and you figure out how to avoid it. The boss puts out its patterns and you avoid it. You land a blow. Patiently you wait for another opening. Another blow. You fight for what seems an eternity however you quickly notice it's close to dying. Patiently you wait for your last blow to be struck. You swing and you hear the beast screech and fade away. The feeling after you kill what had been troubling you is overwhelming in this game however since I have put so much time and effort into this game the effects have begun to wane but I remember it clearly.So to sum it up, the game isn't super difficult and can be mastered very quickly with a mind of the willing to learn, it has tons of lore which makes the game deep. The bosses and areas have loads of variants and are all interesting in their own way.So yes I recommend that you get Dark Souls and experience it.Note: Please do not buy this game for the purpose of playing with a friend.Yes it does have co-op and PvP but actually playing with your friend is a difficult process which usually requires tons of waiting or modified files.

content:
ry 24, 2015
												If the horror stories are to be believed, Dark Souls is a punishing game that only those with infinite patience will ever see the end of. As with so many legends, there’s a grain of truth to these claims that’s been exaggerated out of proportion; yes, Dark Souls is a merciless beast whose demanding nature will put off a lot of people. But is it insurmountable for the average gaming enthusiast? I’d argue no.After a cryptic intro that raises more questions than it answers, Dark Souls places you in a prison cell armed with only a broken sword. On top of that, your character died before you even had a say in their life. All this sets the tone for an adventure that pulls no punches, and by the time you find a decent weapon you’ll have already run into some lethal creatures. But there’s nothing inherently unreasonable about the opening segment of gameplay; you’re told what buttons do what, then given a weapon and left to figure out the most efficient means of killing stuff with it. The result is a game that trains you to approach new areas with caution, never underestimate an opponent, and always have an escape route if things go ♥♥♥♥-up. It’s an intriguing hybrid of old and new game design, sans most of the cryptic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ your nostalgia doesn’t let you remember.The combat is the dominant gameplay feature, of course, and I don’t hesitate to call it some of the best I’ve seen: a dagger feels completely different from a giant hammer, and neither can be called definitively better than the other. Dodging attacks and getting backstabs is a legitimate tactic, but so is tanking damage and punching through blocks with heavy weapons, not to mention the abundance of magical options I was too scared to try for a long time. It’s a strategic experience that something like Skyrim can barely dream of unless modded up the wazoo.Speaking of strategy, Dark Souls is one of precious few games that actually give meaningful penalties for death. Every time you die, you lose your accumulated points and have precisely one chance to retrieve them. If you ♥♥♥♥ that up, the points are gone forever. It’s harsh, to be sure, but checkpoints are never obscenely far apart and I learned early on that if you know your downfall is imminent, you might as well try and die in a spot that can be reached easily. It’s just another system to use to your advantage and will only screw you over if you push your luck: know when to retreat and spend your points, rather than lose them deep in enemy territory. That the entire world respawns when you use a checkpoint is bizarre at first, yet makes a lot of sense to me; sitting at a bonfire becomes a tactical decision, since it provides safety at the cost of undoing your progress elsewhere. And as crushing as it is to lose your hard-earned points, those moments are also the best times to throw yourself at a boss or speed through a tough area to grab items.Navigating the metroidvania landscape is the other great art of Dark Souls. Locales are varied (along with their inhabitants) and frequently bigger than they first appear, overflowing with hidden loot, shortcuts and even optional bosses. Backtracking does become a nuisance beyond a certain point, and the teleport option is hard-earned, but the only places I truly dislike are the handful suffering from framerate dips (on consoles) and finicky platform segments. Other than that, I find the game’s setup enjoyable, not least due to its role in one of Dark Souls’ most surprising triumphs: storytelling.There’s a wealth of lore to be found in subtle background details and item descriptions, and it really felt like I was piecing together the world’s history from the clues left behind. The slow realisation of just how boned the land is fits perfectly with the sense of dread pervading the gameplay, and even your character’s ability to rise after death is contextually justified. For a game that could’ve relied solely on its combat, I find it doubly impressive that Dark Souls manages to have a memorable world, and with a minimalistic style that’s refreshing in an industry whose attempts at storytelling often rely on overwritten cutscenes.Another remarkable aspect of Dark Souls is the online integration: players can leave messages that randomly pop up in people’s worlds. Some are helpful, some are amusing, and some are outright lies. Then you have a clunky but workable co-op mechanic, along with the danger of being invaded by other guys whenever you de-zombify yourself. The whole arrangement is seemingly unique to the Souls franchise, and has created a profound sense of community while also reminding you that nobody can be trusted.At its core, Dark Souls represents a raw yet fair challenge where death is almost never anyone’s fault but the player’s. And while your initial perception may be one of cruel chaos, dig deep enough and you’ll find a sense of order. By almost any measure, I think Dark Souls must be called an impressive piece of work. The only question is whether you’ll enjoy an action game which requires you to be methodical and treat every fight like a matter of life and death. Unlike some parts of the fanbase, I understand that it’s possible to not like something for reasons other than sucking at it.

content:
y 29, 2014
												Dark Souls.... doesnt the name just make you cringe?! Well, it shouldn't! People will play games forever, whether it's marbles or Dark souls, but either way, somebody is gonna rage quit! some people will play a video game just to 'Beat' it. However, this game does it a little different.... instead of giving you a choice of beating it or not, it decides for you - and it's never in your favour! This game beats you.... to a pulp.... then runs you over in it's car.... and gets it's mates to help beat the crap out of you.... not even exaggerating a little bit! But why should that scare you off? It's just a game right?Wrong, ♥♥♥♥♥♥!This is more than a game, it's an achievement, an accomplishment, a challenge and a test for all gamers out there!This game is not reccomended for those who are prone to rage quitting, and it's definately not for the faint at heart!'But what's the point if im just going to die all the time?'Shut up, you're adopted! let me tell you what's in store for you!The rewards may be a few souls and a weapon.... but thats in game! Inside your head you have just played the same part of the game about 500 times, and you've died equally. You were about to walk away when you gave it one more shot! finally, you got the SOB down to its last bit of health and you stabbed it right in the ♥♥♥♥♥! You stood with your head held high when you finally killed that boss and you made it known that you owned it and you had intercourse with it's mother while shouting at the screen. The satisfaction levels are over 9000, and you could even say that you smiled after so much anger and frustration.... and trust me when i say that THAT very smile feels amazing!this game will take you a LONG time to finish..... the first area..... let alone the whole game! but it's not about time, its about how much you want it! it's about your desire to accomplish something! You can say to your weaker friends 'Hey look noob, i finished Dark Souls! what did you do in the last 600 hours of your life?'having said that, this game IS NOT a waste of time at all! if you play for an hour and dont even get to a new bonfire (Checkpoint [Very Rare]) dont decide it's no use, just keep trying.... there are more secrets in this game the illuminati dont even know whats going on!! Look for shortcuts, try new areas dont get caught in a rut!So yeah, thats what i think anyway! please consider playing this game (If you can get it working on steam [Need a games for windows account]) Dark Souls..... You are worthy of nothing less...9.3/10Dylan Burton

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 5, 2014
												Your girlfriend might think "The Notebook" is emotional.  Maybe it is, but it is not even close to being as emotional as Dark Souls.  For while that movie might make her want to cry, Dark Souls will make you run an emotional gauntlet that you have not known since you're early days.  You'll want to throw your controller and scream at your sceen in anger at times.  Then, later, you'll feel your heart racing and breathe a heavy sigh of relief at what obstacle you've finally overcome.  You'll want to tell you're friends, and if they've been through it, they'll know what you're talking about.Don't think for a minute that all of this is because the game is impossibly hard.  On a scale of 1 to "Nintendo Hard", it's probably a 7, if that.  The feelings that come from this game stem from one fact; every death is your fault.  You will know when you tried to block a hit you should have dodged, or when you rolled a second too late in the wrong direction.  The combat is slow and seems clunky at first,  Basically, whenever you attack, or roll, or do anything, you had better mean it.  This is Castlevania 1 stuff right here.  Every button you press has a consequence, and building this discipline is the first hurdle of the game.The first thing players might notice is the lack of a tutorial, save for a few very brief messages scrawled on the ground detailing the game's controls.  You are on your own for everything else, and this is crucial to the game's design.  The first boss will probably kill you a few times while you fumble around.  Soon you'll be able to kill him in your sleep.  There is no voiceover giving you hints and alerts.  There are no markers, or flashing enemy bits detailing weak spots.  Experimentation and persistance are key, and the repeated failures make the experience more memorable.  Who remembers any boss from a game that they beat the first time by running at it and attacking it until it dies?  My Steam Library is full of games that I blew through once and couldn't tell you much about what happened.  I was happy when I played them, but they didn't leave me with anything when they were over.I've never beat a game and had the immediate desire to start it over.  But Dark Souls gives that experience because it dares you to come up with a way to perfect your style.  It is easy at first to make a trash character who is useless.  But even if that character doesn't make it to the end, his experiences keep going with the player, who uses what he learns to get even further.  Of course, a bad character can still make it to the end in the hands of a skilled player, and leveling is totally optional.  Imagine if in Final Fantasy a skilled player could win the game at level 1.  In Dark Souls, it is difficult, but possible.I'll wrap up by saying that the presentation is great as well.  The landscapes are varied and all are memorable in their own way.  The settings have such a personality to them that just saying the word "Blighttown" might cause someone to nod and give you an empathetic grunt.  Most areas have no music, and that is perfect.  It's a lonely game, and the echoes of your characters footsteps add to that effect.  When there is music, generally in bossfights, it is top notch.  There is a story, and it is very good.  The story has a sort of Mythical feel, dealing with immortality, undeath, ancient lords, and lost cities.  Thorough players will be rewarded with tidbits of story from NPCs, item descriptions, and visual cues in the setting, and the player will be left to piece together much of the story for themself.  Multiplayer is definately unique, if not a bit flawed, made frustrating by the fact that high level players can weasel their way into low level areas.  It fits the uncaring nature of the game.  Welcome to Dark Souls.  Prepare to Die...I feel the need to bring up the fact that the PC Port is not the greatest.  Though Games for Windows Live will soon not be an issue, the mod utility "DSFIX" will be very helpfully in covering the port's shorcomings, from help with controls to resolution fixes.  Some of these fixes are pretty taxing on your hardware, so read the guides if you use them.  Also, a controller is pretty much a must in my opinion, this game was not designed for mouse and keyboard.  I used a Playstation 2 controller (seriously) with a 5 dollar adaptor and it worked just fine.

content:
6, 2014
												The most challenging and jolly rewarding game you will play in a long time, Dark Souls combines the dark fantasy theme that gamers have always known and loved with the chalenge that only FromSoftware could get away with while still creating a successfully selling game. With a vaste open world to explore filled with wonderful scenery to gawk at while falling from a cliff while trying to roll away from a flock of hollows, jolly co-operation, a large variety of bosses and mobs alike which force you to adapt how you play in order for them to be mastered and npcs who will steal your heart (in a good way) and guide you on your path as the chosen undead, or not...The only real downside of this game is the inaccessabily of the story, even though this is the direction FromSoft were trying to go with the game, forcing you to uncover the story for yourself rather than shoving it down your throat, this just doesn't work for most. However when uncovered (i suggest youtube for those of you without the time to dig deep enough yourself) the story will pull at your heartstrings and make you question the things you have done an the things you must do aswell as boggling your brain.All in all Dark Souls is a wonderful game well worth the $19.99 you will pay for it and I would recommend it to anyone with the patience to endure it. If only more games could be so grossly incandescent.

content:
y 29, 2014
												Dark Souls.... doesnt the name just make you cringe?! Well, it shouldn't! People will play games forever, whether it's marbles or Dark souls, but either way, somebody is gonna rage quit! some people will play a video game just to 'Beat' it. However, this game does it a little different.... instead of giving you a choice of beating it or not, it decides for you - and it's never in your favour! This game beats you.... to a pulp.... then runs you over in it's car.... and gets it's mates to help beat the crap out of you.... not even exaggerating a little bit! But why should that scare you off? It's just a game right?Wrong, ♥♥♥♥♥♥!This is more than a game, it's an achievement, an accomplishment, a challenge and a test for all gamers out there!This game is not reccomended for those who are prone to rage quitting, and it's definately not for the faint at heart!'But what's the point if im just going to die all the time?'Shut up, you're adopted! let me tell you what's in store for you!The rewards may be a few souls and a weapon.... but thats in game! Inside your head you have just played the same part of the game about 500 times, and you've died equally. You were about to walk away when you gave it one more shot! finally, you got the SOB down to its last bit of health and you stabbed it right in the ♥♥♥♥♥! You stood with your head held high when you finally killed that boss and you made it known that you owned it and you had intercourse with it's mother while shouting at the screen. The satisfaction levels are over 9000, and you could even say that you smiled after so much anger and frustration.... and trust me when i say that THAT very smile feels amazing!this game will take you a LONG time to finish..... the first area..... let alone the whole game! but it's not about time, its about how much you want it! it's about your desire to accomplish something! You can say to your weaker friends 'Hey look noob, i finished Dark Souls! what did you do in the last 600 hours of your life?'having said that, this game IS NOT a waste of time at all! if you play for an hour and dont even get to a new bonfire (Checkpoint [Very Rare]) dont decide it's no use, just keep trying.... there are more secrets in this game the illuminati dont even know whats going on!! Look for shortcuts, try new areas dont get caught in a rut!So yeah, thats what i think anyway! please consider playing this game (If you can get it working on steam [Need a games for windows account]) Dark Souls..... You are worthy of nothing less...9.3/10Dylan Burton

content:
y 20, 2015
												You awaken in a prison cell, hollowed and stripped of all humanity. You are an Undead, a cursed being trapped within the purgatory that is the Undead Asylum. Who you are and what brought you here are a mystery. The curse makes one forget it seems. As you break out of your cell messages written with soapstone start to appear. Slowly you will make your way through the Asylum, heeding the cautionary tales written by those who came before you. You will seek comfort in the warm embrace of the bonfire, an oasis amidst the rubble and death. Before long however, you will be faced with insurmountable odds in the form of the Asylum Demon. This is where you will most likely die. However death isn't the end of things, you're an Undead after all. Soon you'll feel the warm embrace of the bonfire once more. At this point you will try again, again and again. Until at long last you slay the beast and are liberated from this place. This is where Dark Souls starts and your journey begins. That journey will be beautiful and engaging. The world you'll explore, the characters you'll meet are all lovingly crafted and will stick with you until long after. The gameplay is brutally unforgiving and exceptionally rewarding. Every bit of progress you'll make in this game will be a personal victory. It is incredibly captivating, challenging and simply put fun. If you are looking for a lengthy hands off narrative with compelling, tense action orientated D&D style gameplay. Then do yourself a favor, pick this game up and praise the sun!That being said, it is not without it's faults. The port of this game is sloppy to say the least. Natively it runs at sub par resolutions and has it's gamelogic locked at 30fps. This means that out of the box this game is practically unplayable for most PC gamers. Luckily there are ways to fix these glaring issues in the form of DSFix. (V2.4 at the time of this writing) It is a third party injector created for Dark Souls Prepare To Die Edition that enables you to alter render settings at the engine level.All in all I can not recommend Dark Souls enough.Praise the sun!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 17, 2014
												Dark Souls was a game that took me very much by surprise.Being peripherally aware of it around release as something focussed on brutality in its gameplay and its violence; I waved it off at the time as just being another typical 'AAA' title of being all flash and little substance.But was I ever wrong!There's no denying, of course, that Dark Souls  does  revel in difficulty and carnage - but what I actually found was something far, far more enlightened than that.The variety and handling of the gameplay (and I say this having played it only once through,) are immediately to be appreciated themselves.  Every weapon and piece of armour, with few exceptions, feels like it has its place and usefulness.  Every concept of class progression (while still being a fluid and malleable system, as per Elder Scrolls) feels rewarding to further your abilities and play-style.  The multiplayer, even being as indirect a system as it is without any means of direct communication, is a novel and exciting experience.  And the notorious boss fights and difficulty remain exciting and engaging even as they are kicking your ♥♥♥... repeatedly.  It is an 'action RPG', but one that challenges you to be quite deliberate and exacting in your methods.In terms of media, the game is an incredibly lovely experience to bask in as well.  Though the drive to look for the next monster to kill or quest to complete (or death to avoid) can push you along at a fairly brisk pace; if you take the time to admire your surroundings, every region of the game world is filled to the brim with character.  The amount of variety in said monsters is no less astonishing either, mark you, as everywhere you venture will have at least one creature that will give you pause to admire how cool/gruesome/terrifying a work the artists of this game have concocted.  The music meanwhile provides the right amount of background ambience to fill in the regions and add excitement to your challenges without coming across as too contrived or fantastical, always feeling very fitting to the dark and dangerous ambience of the game.  Both of these, perhaps best yet, are blended together beautifully in the game's masterfully done cutscenes.  The pacing, the camera placement, the description of them are truly highwater marks of cinematography in games.If there's a shortcoming to cite about this game, for me, it is the story's own lack of exposure.  After the opening cinematics and character creation set you off on the right foot - you suddenly feel like you've been thrust into a world filled with rich creative lore, but which will only ever show itself in snippets at a time.  I will entirely advocate the value and the power of games leaving things to the player's imagination, and cannot help but frown when a fictional universe will try to introduce itself too strongly or comprehensively; but this is one feels like it's just teasing us!  I found myself reading every item's description and hunting out every last piece of dialogue to try to understand the world going on around me, but it mostly felt like it was lurking just outside of my reach.  You're left with the distant feeling that your actions are meaningful, but are rarely quite sure why.The ambiguity extends to some of the gameplay itself as well; and while the spirit of the game is very much in the trial-and-error of learning your way through boss fights and other challenges through death after death - how you would be expected to know to head to a given area next or meet up again with another character at a potentially previous location - or what how the character stats, item upgrades, and scaling really come into the game... is something that puzzles me.  Without the knowledge from public wikis and forums, or at least an informed friend; I reckon that this game would be otherwise nigh impossible to comprehensively explore and experience if left your own devices.Nevertheless; such criticism is more than overshowed by the game's strengths - and it remains an incredibly immersive experience, even if and when you wish you knew just a little bit more of what was going on.  To be able to offer exciting and rewarding gameplay; a gorgeous artistic backdrop; *and* thought-provoking characters and themes (the ones you get a look at, anyway) - Dark Souls is a thoroughly worthwhile experience, and my strongest recommendations go with it.
